{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} A '''501(c) organization''' is a [[nonprofit organization]] in the [[Law_of_the_United_States#Federal_law|federal law of the United States]] according to {{usc|26|501}} and is one of 29 types of nonprofit organizations exempt from some [[Taxation in the United States|federal]] [[Income tax in the United States|income taxes]]. Sections 503 through 505 set out the requirements for attaining such exemptions. Many states refer to Section 501(c) for definitions of organizations exempt from state taxation as well. 501(c) organizations can receive unlimited contributions from individuals, [[corporation]]s, and [[labor union|unions]].
For example, a nonprofit organization may be tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) if its primary activities are charitable, religious, educational, scientific, literary, testing for public safety, fostering amateur sports competition, preventing [[child abuse|cruelty to children]], or preventing [[animal cruelty|cruelty to animals]].
==Types== According to the IRS Publication 557, in the ''Organization Reference Chart'' section, the following is an exact list of 501(c) organization types and their corresponding descriptions.<ref>{{cite web |title= Publication 557: Tax-Exempt Status For Your Organization |work= Internal Revenue Service |pages= 65–66 |date= June 2008 |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p557.pdf |accessdate= January 27, 2009 }}</ref>{{efn|name=ISA1950|In accordance with the [[McCarran Internal Security Act|Internal Security Act of 1950]], any 501(c), 501(d), or 521 organization loses its tax-exempt status in any taxable year during which the organization is a communist-action organization or a communist-infiltrated organization.<ref>"[https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CFR-2001-title26-vol7/pdf/CFR-2001-title26-vol7-sec1-501k-1.pdf § 1.501(k)–1]". ''Internal Revenue Service''.</ref>}}
* 501(c)(1) – Corporations Organized Under Act of Congress (including [[Federal Credit Union Act|Federal Credit Unions]]) * 501(c)(2) – Title-holding Corporations for Exempt Organizations<ref>{{cite web |title= IRC 501(c)(2) Title-holding Corporations |work= 1986 EO CPE Text |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |year= 1986 |accessdate=2 July 2012 |format= pdf |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicc86.pdf}}</ref> * [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c)(3)]] – Religious, Educational, Charitable, Scientific, Literary, Testing for Public Safety, to Foster National or International Amateur Sports Competition, or Prevention of Cruelty to Children or Animals Organizations * [[#501(c)(4)|501(c)(4)]] – Civic Leagues, Social Welfare Organizations, and Local Associations of Employees * [[#501(c)(5)|501(c)(5)]] – Labor, Agricultural and Horticultural Organizations * [[#501(c)(6)|501(c)(6)]] – Business Leagues, Chambers of Commerce, Real Estate Boards, etc. * [[#501(c)(7)|501(c)(7)]] – Social and Recreational Clubs * [[#501(c)(8)|501(c)(8)]] – [[Benefit society|Fraternal Beneficiary Societies and Associations]] * 501(c)(9) – [[Voluntary Employee Beneficiary Association]]s * 501(c)(10) – Domestic Fraternal Societies and Associations * 501(c)(11) – Teachers' Retirement Fund Associations * 501(c)(12) – Benevolent Life Insurance Associations, Mutual Ditch or Irrigation Companies, Mutual or [[Utility cooperative|Cooperative Telephone Companies]], etc. * [[#501(c)(13)|501(c)(13)]] – [[Cemetery]] Companies * 501(c)(14) – State-Chartered [[Credit Union]]s, Mutual Reserve Funds * 501(c)(15) – [[Mutual Insurance]] Companies or Associations * 501(c)(16) – Cooperative Organizations to Finance Crop Operations * 501(c)(17) – Supplemental Unemployment Benefit Trusts * 501(c)(18) – Employee Funded Pension Trust (created before June 25, 1959) * 501(c)(19) – Post or Organization of Past or Present Members of the [[United States Armed Forces|Armed Forces]] * 501(c)(20) – Group Legal Services Plan Organizations{{efn|501(c)(20) organizations are no longer tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(20) after June 30, 1992, but they may request to become exempt under Section 501(c)(9) effective July 1, 1992.<ref>{{cite web |title= Publication 557: Tax Exempt Status for Your Organization |page= 60 |work= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p557.pdf }}</ref> }} * 501(c)(21) – [[Coalworker's pneumoconiosis|Black Lung]] Benefit Trusts * 501(c)(22) – Withdrawal Liability Payment Fund * 501(c)(23) – Veterans Organizations{{efn|Veterans organizations may be exempt under Section 501(c)(23) only if the organization was created before 1880. Other veterans organizations may be exempt under Section 501(c)(4) instead. }} * 501(c)(24) – Section 4049 [[Employee Retirement Income Security Act|ERISA]] Trusts{{efn|501(c)(24) organizations are described as Section 4049 ERISA Trusts; Section 4049 of [[ERISA]] has been repealed.<ref>{{cite web |title= 29 USC § 1349 |work= Legal Information Institute |publisher= Cornell University Law School |accessdate=16 May 2013 |url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/29/1349 }}</ref> }} * 501(c)(25) – Title Holding Corporations or Trusts with Multiple Parents * 501(c)(26) – State-Sponsored Organization Providing Health Coverage for High-Risk Individuals * 501(c)(27) – State-Sponsored Workers' Compensation [[Reinsurance]] Organization * 501(c)(28) – National [[Railroad Retirement Board|Railroad Retirement]] Investment Trust * 501(c)(29) – Qualified Nonprofit Health Insurance Issuers{{efn|The Section 501(c)(29) tax exemption for qualified nonprofit health Insurance issuers was created in section 1322(h)(1) of the [[Affordable Care Act]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Guidance on Requirements for Tax-Exempt 501(c)(29) Qualified Nonprofit Health Insurance Issuers |work=Internal Revenue Service |date=March 11, 2011 |url=https://www.irs.gov/charities/article/0,,id=237287,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110315013801/https://www.irs.gov/charities/article/0%2C%2Cid%3D237287%2C00.html |archivedate=15 March 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> }}
===Other tax-exempt organizations=== * 501(d) – Religious or [[Apostolic poverty|apostolic]] organizations with the purpose of operating a religious community where the members live a communal life following the tenets and teachings of the organization.<ref name= 501d>{{cite web |title= Part 4. Examining Process: Chapter 76. Exempt Organizations Examination Guidelines: Section 29. Apostolic Associations – IRC 501(d) |work= Internal Revenue Manual |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/irm/part4/irm_04-076-029.html }}</ref> The organization's property is owned by each of the individuals in the community but, upon leaving, a member cannot withdraw any of the community's assets.<ref name= 501d/> The organization's income goes into a community treasury that is used to pay for the organization's operating expenses and supporting members and their families.<ref name= 501d/><ref>Rev. Rul. 57-574, 1957-2 c.b. 161.</ref>{{efn|name=ISA1950}} * 501(e) – Cooperative hospital service organizations that are organized to provide services for multiple tax-exempt hospitals.<ref>{{cite web |title= 26 CFR 1.501(e)-1 - Cooperative hospital service organizations |work= Legal Services Institute |url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/1.501(e)-1 }}</ref> * 501(f) – Cooperative service organizations of educational organizations that invest assets contributed by each of the organization's members.<ref>{{cite web |title= 26 U.S. Code § 501(e) |work= Legal Information Institute |url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/501 }}</ref> * 501(j) – Amateur sports organizations that either conduct national or international sporting competitions or develop amateur athletes for national or international sporting competitions.<ref name="501j">[[Wikisource:United States Code/Title 26/Chapter 1/Subchapter F/Part I/Section 501#j]]</ref> * 501(k) – [[Day care|Day care center]]s may qualify as tax-exempt under Section 501(k).<ref name="501k-1">[[Wikisource:United States Code/Title 26/Chapter 1/Subchapter F/Part I/Section 501#k]]</ref><ref name="501k-2">{{cite web |title= Part 7. Rulings and Agreements; Chapter 25. Exempt Organizations Determinations Manual; Section 3. Religious, Charitable, Educational, Etc., Organizations (Cont. 1); 7.25.3.7.11.4 (02-23-1999) Child Care Organizations |work= Internal Revenue Service |accessdate=29 July 2013 |url= https://www.irs.gov/irm/part7/irm_07-025-003-cont01.html }}</ref><ref name="501k-3">{{cite web |title= IRC 501(k) – Child Care Organizations |work= 1986 EO CPE Text |year= 1986 |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicd86.pdf }}</ref> The day care center must provide child care away from their homes.<ref name="501k-2" /> At least 85 percent of the children served must be cared for while their parent or guardian is either employed, seeking employment, or a full-time student.<ref name="501k-4">{{cite web |title= IRC 501(k) – Child Care Organization |work= 1989 EO CPE Text |year= 1989 |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopich89.pdf }}</ref> Most of the day care center's funding must come from fees received for day care services.<ref name="501k-4" /> The day care center must also provide child care services to the general public.<ref name="501k-2" /> The tax exemption for certain day care centers was part of the [[Deficit Reduction Act of 1984]].<ref name="501k-3" /> * 501(n) – Charitable risk pools that pool insurable risks of its members, which are tax-exempt charities.<ref>{{cite web |title= 26 U.S.C. § 501(n) |work= FindLaw |publisher= Thompson Reuters |url= http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/uscode/26/A/1/F/I/501 }}</ref> * 521(a) – Farmers' cooperative associations that market its member farmers' products at market rates, make purchases at wholesale rates, and remit earnings to member farmers.<ref>{{cite web |title= Part 4. Examining Process: Chapter 44. Subchapter T Cooperatives: Section 1. IRC section 521 Exempt Farmers' Cooperatives |work= Internal Revenue Manual |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/irm/part4/irm_04-044-001.html }}</ref>{{efn|name=ISA1950}} * 527 – [[527 organization|Political organizations]] that operate primarily to raise or spend money to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any Federal, State, or local public office,<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/527 26 U.S. Code § 527 - Political organizations]". ''Legal Information Institute''. Accessed December 4, 2015.</ref> such as [[political parties]], [[political action committee]]s, and [[Political action committee#Super PACs|Super PAC]]s. * 528 – Homeowner associations, condominium management associations, residential real estate management associations, and timeshare associations may elect to be exempt from income tax on their exempt-function income under Section 528.<ref name= porter>Porter, Gary. "[http://501c4taxexempt.com/ 501(c)(4) Tax Exempt Homeowners Associations]". Hinricher, Douglas & Porter, LLP. Accessed March 1, 2016.</ref><ref>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/528 26 U.S. Code § 528 - Certain homeowners associations]". ''Legal Information Institute''. Cornell University Law School. Accessed March 1, 2016.</ref><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i1120h.pdf 2015 Instructions for Form 1120-H: U.S. Income Tax Return for Homeowners Associations]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Accessed on March 1, 2016.</ref><ref name= irs-hoa>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicr82.pdf Homeowners' Associations Under IRC 501(c)(4), 501(c)(7) and 528]". ''Exempt Organizations Continuing Professional Education Text''. [[Internal Revenue Service]]. 1982.</ref> Alternatively, some homeowner associations may qualify under Section [[501(c)(4)]] instead.<ref name= porter/><ref name= irs-hoa/> A homeowner association that provides only social and recreational activities may qualify under Section [[501(c)(7)]].<ref name= irs-hoa/> * 529 – [[529 plan|Qualified tuition plans]] operated by a state or educational institution.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/uac/529-plans-questions-and-answers 529 Plans: Questions and Answers]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. August 24, 2015.</ref> * 4947(a)(1) – Non-exempt charitable trusts that have exclusively charitable interests.<ref name= 4947a>{{cite web |title= Part 7. Rulings and Agreements: Chapter 26. Private Foundations Manual: Section 15. IRC 4947 Trusts |work= Internal Revenue Manual |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/irm/part7/irm_07-026-015.html }}</ref> * 4947(a)(2) – Split-interest trusts.<ref name= 4947a/> * 170(c)(1) – Government entities in the United States.<ref>"[https://learn.guidestar.org/help/irs-subsection-codes IRS Subsection Codes for Tax Exempt Organizations]". ''[[Guidestar]]''. Retrieved August 5, 2016.</ref> * 892(a) – Foreign governments.<ref name= irc892>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/892 Internal Revenue code 892]". ''Legal Information Institute''. Cornell University Law School. Retrieved September 27, 2018.</ref><ref name= eotopick92>Bloom, James F.; Luft, Edward D.; Reilly, John F. (1992). "[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopick92.pdf Foreign Activities of Domestic Charities and Foreign Charities]". ''Exempt Organizations Continuing Professional Education Text''. Internal Revenue Service. p. 5.</ref> * 892(b) – Public international organizations or international-organization preparatory commissions in which the Government of the United States participates.<ref name= irc892/><ref name= eotopick92/>
==General compliance== Under Section 511, a 501(c) organization is subject to tax on its "[[unrelated business income]]", whether or not the organization actually makes a profit, but not including selling donated merchandise or other business or trade carried on by volunteers, or certain bingo games.<ref>{{usc|26|513(f)}}.</ref> Disposal of donated goods valued over $2,500, or acceptance of goods worth over $5,000 may also trigger special filing and record-keeping requirements.
Tax exemption does not excuse an organization from maintaining proper records and filing any required annual or special-purpose [[tax return (United States)|tax returns]], e.g., {{usc|26|6033}} and {{usc|26|6050L}}. Prior to 2008, an annual return was not generally required from an exempt organization accruing less than $25,000 in gross income yearly.<ref>Internal Revenue Bulletin 23, 1982, exercising {{usc|26|6033(a)(2)(B)}}.</ref> Since 2008, most organizations whose annual gross receipts are less than $50,000 must file an annual information return known as [[Form 990|Form 990-N]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.irs.gov/charities/article/0,,id=169250,00.html |title=Annual Electronic Filing Requirement for Small Exempt Organizations – Form 990-N (e-Postcard) |work= Internal Revenue Service |date= 29 June 2016 }}</ref>{{efn|name=990Nexceptions|Organizations that are not eligible to file Form 990-N include private foundations, most section 509(a)(3) supporting organizations, and organizations exempt under Section 501(c)(1), 501(c)(20), 501(c)(23), 501(c)(24), 501(d), 527, 529, 4947(a)(2), 4947(a)(1).<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/form-990-n-e-postcard-organizations-not-permitted-to-file Form 990-N (e-Postcard): Organizations Not Permitted to File]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. February 29, 2016.</ref>}} Form 990-N must be submitted electronically using an authorized [[IRS e-file]] provider. Form 990, Form 990-EZ, and Form 990-PF may be filed either by mail or electronically through an authorized e-file provider.
Failure to file required returns such as Form 990 (Return of Organization Exempt From Income Tax) may result in fines of up to $250,000 per year. Exempt or political organizations, excluding churches or similar religious entities, must make their returns, reports, notices, and exempt applications available for public inspection. The organization's Form 990 (or similar such public record as the Form 990-EZ or Form 990-PF) is available for public inspection and photocopying at the offices of the exempt organization, through a written request and payment for photocopies by mail from the exempt organization, or through a direct Form 4506-A "Request for Public Inspection or Copy or Political Organization IRS Form" request to the IRS of for the past three tax years. Form 4506-A also allows the public inspection or photocopying access to Form 1023 "Application for Recognition of Exemption" or Form 1024, Form 8871 "Political Organization Notice of Section 527 Status", and Form 8872 "Political Organization Report of Contribution and Expenditures". Internet access to many organizations' 990 and some other forms are available through [[GuideStar]].{{efn|name=Guidestar|[[Guidestar]] access to recent 990 filings is available for free, but requires one to open a free account.<ref>"[http://learn.guidestar.org/about-us/ About Us]". ''[[Guidestar]]''. Accessed on June 29, 2016.</ref>}} Certain organizations are exempt from filing Form 990, such as churches, their integrated auxiliaries, and conventions or associations of churches; the exclusively religious activities of any religious order; and religious organizations; and most organizations whose annual gross receipts are less than $5,000.<ref>{{usc|26|6033}}</ref> Failure to file such timely returns and to make other specific information available to the public also is prohibited.<ref>{{usc|26|6652}}</ref><ref>{{usc|26|6104}}</ref>
==501(c)(3)== {{Main article|501(c)(3) organization}} 501(c)(3) tax-exemptions apply to entities that are organized and operated exclusively for [[religion|religious]], [[Charitable organization|charitable]], [[science|scientific]], [[literature|literary]], or [[education]]al purposes, or for testing for public safety, or to foster national or international [[amateur sports]] competition, or for the prevention of cruelty to children or [[Cruelty to animals|animals]]. The 501(c)(3) exemption also applies for any unincorporated [[Community Chest (organization)|community chest]], fund, [[Cooperating Associations|cooperating association]], or foundation that is organized and operated exclusively for those purposes.<ref>[https://www.irs.gov/Charities-&-Non-Profits/Charitable-Organizations/Exempt-Purposes-Internal-Revenue-Code-Section-501(c)(3) Exempt Purposes – Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3)].</ref><ref>[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p557.pdf IRS Publication 557 "Tax-Exempt Status For Your Organization", Page 19, (Rev. June 2008), Cat. No 46573C.], Retrieved 2009-03-09.</ref> There are also supporting organizations—often referred to in shorthand form as "Friends of" organizations.<ref name="Hopkins2011">{{citation | last=Hopkins | first=Bruce R. | year=2011 | title=The Law of Tax-Exempt Organizations | edition=10 | publisher=John Wiley and Sons | isbn=978-0-470-60217-1 | page=879 }}</ref><ref>Judith S. Ballan, "How To Aid a Foreign Charity Through an 'American Friends of' Organization", in Proceedings of the Twenty-Third New York University Conference on Tax Planning.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usig.org/legal/friends_of_organizations.asp |title=Legal Dimensions of International Grantmaking: How a Private Foundation Can Use "Friends of" Organizations |publisher=Usig.org |date= |accessdate=7 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916031540/http://www.usig.org/legal/friends_of_organizations.asp |archivedate=16 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://gi.philanthropycapital.org/views/33/meet-the-expert-suzanne-m-reisman-law-offices-of-suzanne-m-reisman |title=Meet the expert: Suzanne M. Reisman, Law Offices of Suzanne M. Reisman |publisher=Giving Insights |date=2010-03-03 |accessdate=7 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817055444/http://gi.philanthropycapital.org/views/33/meet-the-expert-suzanne-m-reisman-law-offices-of-suzanne-m-reisman |archivedate=17 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Larkin2011">{{citation | last1=Larkin | first1=Richard F. | year=2011 | title=Wiley Not-for-Profit GAAP 2011: Interpretation and Application of Generally Accepted Accounting Principles | last2=DiTommaso | first2=Marie | publisher=John Wiley and Sons | isbn=978-0-470-55445-6 | page=Ch.11 }}</ref> {{usc|26|170}}, provides a deduction, for federal income tax purposes, for some donors who make [[Charitable contribution deductions in the United States|charitable contributions]] to most types of 501(c)(3) organizations, among others.
Organizations described in section 501(c)(3) are prohibited from conducting [[political campaign]] activities to intervene in [[election]]s to public office.<ref name="IRS-501c3">{{cite web |url=https://www.irs.gov/Charities-&-Non-Profits/Charitable-Organizations/The-Restriction-of-Political-Campaign-Intervention-by-Section-501(c)(3)-Tax-Exempt-Organizations |title=The Restriction of Political Campaign Intervention by Section 501(c)(3) Tax-Exempt Organizations |website=Irs.gov |date=2012-08-14 |accessdate=9 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202054714/https://www.irs.gov/charities/charitable/article/0%2C%2Cid%3D163395%2C00.html |archivedate=2 December 2010 |publisher=[[Internal Revenue Service]] |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On the other hand, public charities (but not private foundations) may conduct a limited amount of [[lobbying]] to influence legislation. Although the law states that "No substantial part..." of a public charity's activities can go to lobbying, charities may register for a [[501(h) election]] allowing them to lawfully conduct lobbying activities as long as their financial expenditure does not exceed a specified amount.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/charities/charitable/article/0,,id=120703,00.html |title=Political and Lobbying Activities |publisher=Irs.gov |date=2009-01-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507002752/https://www.irs.gov/charities/charitable/article/0%2C%2Cid%3D120703%2C00.html |archivedate=7 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=3 June 2014 }}</ref> 501(c)(3) organizations risk loss of tax exempt status if any of these rules are violated.<ref>{{cite web| title = Lobbying| publisher = [[Internal Revenue Service]]| date = 2013-04-18 | url = https://www.irs.gov/Charities-&-Non-Profits/Lobbying |accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref>Amelia Elacqua, [http://www.hbtlj.org/v08p1/v08p1elacquaar.pdf Eyes wide shut: The ambiguous "political activity" prohibition and its effects on 501(c)(3) organizations, ''Houston Business and Tax Journal'', 2008, page 119 and 141, referenced February 16, 2012]</ref>
A 501(c)(3) organization is allowed to conduct some or all of its charitable activities outside the United States.<ref name="71-460">"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr71-460.pdf Rev. Rul. 71-460, 1971-2 C.B. 231]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1971.</ref><ref name="1983eo-o">"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopico83.pdf Domestic Organizations with Foreign Operations]". ''Exempt Organization Continuing Professional Education Text''. Internal Revenue Service. 1983.</ref> Donors' contributions to a 501(c)(3) organization are tax-deductible only if the contribution is for the use of the 501(c)(3) organization, and that the 501(c)(3) organization is not merely serving as an agent or conduit of a foreign charitable organization.<ref name="63-252">"[http://www.bradfordtaxinstitute.com/Endnotes/Rev_Rul_63-252.pdf Rev. Rul. 63-252, 1963-2 C.B. 101]". ''Internal Revenue Service'' via Bradford Tax Institute. 1963.</ref> Additional procedures are required of 501(c)(3) organizations that are [[Private foundation (United States)|private foundation]]s.<ref name="1983eo-o" /><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-wd/0504031.pdf Memorandum 200504031]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. January 28, 2005.</ref>
==501(c)(4)== {{See also|Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission}}
A '''501(c)(4) organization''' is a social welfare organization, such as a civic organization or a neighborhood association. An organization is considered by the IRS to be operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare if it is primarily engaged in promoting the common good and general welfare of the people of the community.<ref name="cpe">{{cite web |title= Political Organizations and IRC IRC 501(c)(4) |first1=Raymond |last1=Chick |first2=Amy |last2=Henchey |work= Exempt Organizations-Technical Instruction Program for FY 1995 |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicm95.pdf }}</ref><ref name="Reg1501">[http://www.taxalmanac.org/index.php/Treasury_Regulations,_Subchapter_A,_Sec._1.501(c)(4)-1 Reg. 1.501(c)(4)-1(a)(2)(i)]</ref> Net earnings must be exclusively used for charitable, educational, or recreational purposes.<ref>See {{usc|26|501(c)(4)(A)}}.</ref>
According to ''[[The Washington Post Co|The Washington Post]]'', 501(c)(4) organizations:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2013/05/13/what-is-a-501c4-anyway/|title=What is a 501(c)(4), anyway?|last=Sullivan|first=Sean|date=2013-05-13|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><blockquote>...are allowed to participate in politics, so long as politics do not become their primary focus. What that means in practice is that they must spend less than 50 percent of their money on politics. So long as they don't run afoul of that threshold, the groups can influence elections, which they typically do through advertising.</blockquote>
===Allowed activities===
501(c)(4) are similar to 501(c)(5) and 501(c)(6) in that the organizations may inform the public on controversial subjects and attempt to influence legislation relevant to its program<ref>{{cite web |title= Rev. Rul. 68-656, 1968-2 C.B. 216 |work= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.irs.gov%2Fpub%2Firs-tege%2Frr68-656.pdf }}</ref> and, unlike 501(c)(3) organizations, they may also participate in political campaigns and elections, as long as their primary activity is the promotion of social welfare and related to the organization's purpose.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.irs.gov/irm/part7/irm_07-025-004.html#d0e332 |work= Internal Revenue Manual |title= Part 7. Rulings and Agreements, Chapter 25. Exempt Organizations Determinations Manual, Section 4. Civic Leagues, Social Welfare Organizations and Local Associations of Employees |agency= Internal Revenue Service }}</ref><ref name= everything/>
The income tax exemption for 501(c)(4) organizations applies to most of their operations, but income spent on political activities—generally the advocacy of a particular candidate in an election—is taxable.<ref>{{cite web |title=Comparison of 501(c) (3)s, 501(c)(4)s, and political organizations |url=http://www.afj.org/assets/resources/resource1/Comparison-of-501C3S-501C4S.pdf |publisher=[[Alliance for Justice]] |date=July 2007 |access-date=15 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215144849/http://www.afj.org/assets/resources/resource1/Comparison-of-501C3S-501C4S.pdf |archive-date=15 February 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> An "action" organization generally qualifies as a 501(c)(4) organization.<ref>{{cite web|title= Rev. Rul. 67-293, 1967-2 C.B. 185 |work= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr67-293.pdf }}</ref> An "action" organization is one whose activities substantially include, or are exclusively,<ref>{{cite web |title= Rev. Rul. 71-530, 1971-2 C.B. 237 |work= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr71-530.pdf }}</ref> direct or [[grassroots]] lobbying related to advocacy for or against legislation or proposing, supporting, or opposing legislation that is related to its purpose.<ref>{{cite web |title= Section 1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(3)(iv) |work= Internal Revenue Service |publisher= U.S. Government Printing Office | url= http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?c=ecfr&rgn=div8&view=text&node=26:7.0.1.1.1.0.1.3&idno=26 }}</ref>
A 501(c)(4) organization may directly or indirectly support or oppose a candidate for public office as long as such activities are not a substantial amount of its activities.<ref name="cpe" /><ref>{{cite web |title= 1.501(c)(4)-1(a)(2)(ii) | work= Internal Revenue Service |url= http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=97f85766bcbc7aecd25d333c3f192923&rgn=div8&view=text&node=26:7.0.1.1.1.0.1.4&idno=26 }}</ref>
A 501(c)(4) organization that lobbies must register with the [[Clerk of the House]] if it lobbies members of the House or their staff.<ref name= everything>{{cite news |title= Everything you need to know about the IRS scandal in one FAQ |last= Matthews |first= Dylan |work= The Washington Post |date= May 14, 2013 |url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/1350661822/}}</ref> Likewise, a 501(c)(4) organization must register with the [[Secretary of the Senate]] if it lobbies members of the Senate or their staff.<ref name= everything/> In addition, the 501(c)(4) organization must either inform its members the amount it spends on lobbying or pay a proxy tax to the Internal Revenue Service.<ref name= everything/> Lobbying expenses and political expenses are not deductible as business expenses.<ref name= everything/>
====Electioneering communications==== The use of 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), and 501(c)(6) organizations has been affected by the 2007 [[FEC v. Wisconsin Right to Life, Inc.]], in which the Supreme Court struck the part of the [[Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act|McCain-Feingold Act]] that prohibited 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), and 501(c)(6) from broadcasting electioneering communications. The Act defined an electioneering communication as a communication that mentions a candidate's name 60 days before a primary or 30 days before a general election.
===Contributions=== Contributions to 501(c)(4) organizations are not tax-deductible as charitable donations unless the organization is either a volunteer fire department or a veterans organization.<ref>Walden, Steve. "Not all charitable gifts tax-deductible, IRS says". ''The Oklahoman'' (Oklahoma City, Oklahoma). February 14, 1983.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Donations to Section 501(c)(4) Organizations|url=https://www.irs.gov/Charities-&-Non-Profits/Other-Non-Profits/Donations-to-Section-501(c)(4)-Organizations|date=2012-08-14|accessdate=31 October 2012}}</ref> Dues or contributions to 501(c)(4) organizations may be deductible as a business expense under IRC 162, although amounts paid for intervention or participation in any political campaign, direct lobbying, grass roots lobbying, and contact with certain federal officials are not deductible.<ref name="cpe2003">{{cite web |title = Political Campaign and Lobbying Activities of IRC 501(c)(4), (c)(5), and (c)(6) Organizations |first1= John Francis |last1= Reilly |first2= Barbara A. |last2= Braig Allen |work= Exempt Organizations-Technical Instruction Program for FY 2003 |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicl03.pdf }}</ref> If a 501(c)(4) engages in a substantial number of these activities, then only the amount of dues or contributions that can be attributed to other activities may be deductible as a business expense.<ref>{{cite web |title= Reg. 1.162-20(c)(3) |work= Internal Revenue Service |publisher= vLex |url= http://cfr.vlex.com/vid/attributable-campaigns-attempts-legislation-19700539 |access-date= 15 June 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20131110191727/http://cfr.vlex.com/vid/attributable-campaigns-attempts-legislation-19700539 |archive-date= 10 November 2013 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
The organization must provide a notice to its members containing a reasonable estimate of the amount related to lobbying and political campaign expenditures, or else it is subject to a proxy tax on its lobbying and political campaign expenditures. It must also state that contributions to the organization are not deductible as charitable contributions during fundraising.<ref name="cpe2003" />
A 501(c)(4) organization is not required to disclose their donors publicly,<ref>{{cite web |title=Political activity of environmental groups and their supporting foundations |url=http://epw.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Files.View&FileStore_id=142d595f-411a-4057-b495-029a095fe25f |page=6|date=September 2008 |publisher=U. S. Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works |accessdate=10 March 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100305232440/http://epw.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Files.View&FileStore_id=142d595f-411a-4057-b495-029a095fe25f| archivedate = 5 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> with the exception of organizations that make [[independent expenditures]] as of 2018.<ref name= fec1/><ref name= fec2/><ref name= fec3/><ref name= fec4/> The former complete lack of disclosure led to extensive use of the 501(c)(4) provisions for organizations that are actively involved in [[lobbying]], and has become controversial.<ref>{{cite news |title=Groups hide behind tax code |last= Adair |first=Bill |work =St. Petersburg Times |date = December 11, 2006 |url= http://www.sptimes.com/2006/12/11/Worldandnation/Groups_hide_behind_ta.shtml}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/21/us/politics/21money.html |title = Donor Names Remain Secret as Rules Shift |last1=Luo |first1=Michael |first2=Stephanie |last2=Strom |work=New York Times |date=September 20, 2010}}</ref> Criticized as "[[dark money]]", spending from these organizations on political advertisements has exceeded spending from [[Super PAC]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/two-dark-money-groups-outspending-all-super-pacs-combined|title= Two Dark Money Groups Outspending All Super PACs Combined | work = ProPublica|author=Kim Barker|date =13 August 2012|accessdate=30 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://projects.propublica.org/dark-money |title= How Some Nonprofit Groups Funnel Dark Money Into Campaigns| work = ProPublica|author= Kim Barker|date=4 October 2012 | accessdate =30 May 2014}}</ref> Spending by organizations that do not disclose their donors increased from less than $5.2 million in 2006 to well over $300 million during the 2012 election season.<ref>{{cite web| title = Political Nonprofits|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/outsidespending/nonprof_summ.php |work= website|publisher=opensecrets.org|accessdate=31 May 2014|date=30 May 2014}}</ref>
Every organization, including a 501(c)(4) organization, that [[independent expenditure|expressly advocates for the election or defeat of a particular political candidate]] and spends more than $250 during a calendar year must disclose the name of each person who contributed more than $200 during the calendar year to the [[Federal Election Commission]].<ref name= fec1>"[http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=(title:52%20section:30104%20edition:prelim) 52 U.S.C. Section 30104(c)]". via ''United States House of Representatives''. Retrieved September 19, 2018.</ref><ref name= fec3>Lee, Michelle Ye Hee; Barnes, Robert (September 18, 2018). "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/political-nonprofits-must-now-name-many-of-their-donors-under-federal-court-ruling-after-supreme-court-declines-to-intervene/2018/09/18/851ea210-bb72-11e8-9812-a389be6690af_story.html?utm_term=.260907277e24 Political nonprofits must now name many of their donors under federal court ruling after Supreme Court declines to intervene]". ''The Washington Post''.</ref> The Federal Election Commission is required to enforce this provision based on a [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|federal court]] decision in 2018.<ref name= fec2>"[http://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=(title:52%20section:30104%20edition:prelim) Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, et al. v. Federal Election Commission and Crossroads Grassroots Strategies]". ''United States District Court for the District of Columbia''. August 3, 2018.</ref><ref name= fec4>"[https://s3.amazonaws.com/storage.citizensforethics.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/18190354/18A274-Crossroads-v.-CREW-Order.pdf Crossroads v. CREW Order]". ''United States Supreme Court''. September 18, 2018.</ref><ref name= fec3/>
===History=== The origins of 501(c)(4) organizations date back to the [[Revenue Act of 1913]], which created a new group of tax-exempt organizations dedicated to social welfare in a precursor to what is now Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(4).<ref>Gershman, Jacob. "[https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2013/05/16/the-surprisingly-muddled-history-of-the-501c4-exemption The Surprisingly Muddled History of the 501(c)(4) Exemption]". ''The Wall Street Journal''. May 16, 2013.</ref>
The Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act of 2015 introduced a new requirement on 501(c)(4) organizations.<ref>"[https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/hr2029/text/enr#link=Q&nearest=H28BF86D91B6D4B0BACAC5DDA239B2E65 H.R.2029: Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016: Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act of 2015: Section 405]". ''Govtrack.us''. Civic Impulse, LLC. December 18, 2015.</ref> Within 60 days of the organization's formation, a 501(c)(4) organization is required to file Form 8976 with the Internal Revenue Service as notification that it is operating as a section 501(c)(4) organization.<ref name = 2016-09>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/n-16-09.pdf Notice 2016-09]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. February 8, 2016.</ref><ref name = 2016-41>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-drop/rp-16-41.pdf Rev. Proc. 2016-41]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. July 11, 2016.</ref> The Internal Revenue Service will acknowledge receipt of the notification, but the acknowledgment is not a determination that the organization qualifies for section 501(c)(4) tax-exempt status.<ref name = 2016-41/> A 501(c)(4) organization is not required to send the notification if the organization was formed on or before July 8, 2016, and it either applied for a determination letter using Form 1024 or filed a Form 990 between December 19, 2015 and July 8, 2016.<ref name = 2016-41/>
As of January 2018, the application for recognition of exemption as a 501(c)(4) organization is a new form, Form 1024-A, rather than Form 1024.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/i1024a.pdf Instructions for Form 1024-A: Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code]". ''Internal Revenue Code''. January 2018.</ref><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f1024a.pdf Form 1024-A: Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code]". ''Internal Revenue Code''. January 2018.</ref>
==501(c)(5)== A '''501(c)(5) organization''' is a labor organization, an agricultural organization, or a horticultural organization. Labor unions, county fairs, and flower societies are examples of these types of groups. Labor union organizations were a primary benefactor of this organization type, dating to the 19th century. According to the Internal Revenue Service, a 501(c)(5) organization has a duty of providing service to its members first. The organization's benefits may not inure to a specific member, but the rules for inurement vary among the three different types of organizations under this segment. A 501(c)(5) organization can make unlimited corporate, individual, or union contributions.<ref name= inurement>{{cite web |url= https://www.irs.gov/Charities-%26-Non-Profits/Charitable-Organizations/Inurement-and-Benefits-to-Members-Agricultural-Horticultural-and-Labor-Organizations-(IRC-501(c)(5)) |title= Inurement and Benefits to Members - Agricultural/Horticultural and Labor Organizations (IRC 501(c)(5)) |work= Internal Revenue Service |date= March 11, 2015 }}</ref>
A labor organization may pay benefits to its members because paying benefits improves all members' shared working conditions. An agricultural organization can provide financial assistance to its members in order to improve the conditions of those engaged in agricultural pursuits generally. Members can benefit in incidental ways from the organization's exempt activities as long as the benefits are available to all persons.<ref name= inurement/>
===History===
The first exemption for labor organizations from corporate income tax was enacted as part of the [[Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act|Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act of 1909]].<ref name= tarriffactof1909>{{cite web |url= https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=X1crAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en&pg=GBS.PA115 |title= Tariff Act of 1909, ch. 6, § 38, 36 Stat. 113 |quote= "That every corporation, joint stock company or association... shall be subject to pay annually a special excise tax with respect to the carrying on or doing business by such corporation, joint stock company or association... Provided, however, That nothing in this section contained shall apply to labor, agricultural or horticultural organizations, or to fraternal beneficiary societies, orders, or associations operating under the lodge system, and providing for the payment of life, sick, accident, and other benefits to the members of such societies, orders, or associations, and dependents of such members, nor to domestic building and loan associations, organized and operated exclusively for the mutual benefit of their members, nor to any corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, or educational purposes, no part of the net income of which inures to the benefit of any private stockholder or individual." }}</ref><ref name= 501c5>{{cite web |title= IRC 501(c)(5) Organizations |first1= John Francis |last1= Reilly |first2= Carter C. |last2= Hull |first3= Barbara A. |last3= Braig Allen |work= Exempt Organizations-Technical Instruction Program for FY 2003 |publisher= Internal Revenue Service |year= 2003 |url= https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicj03.pdf }}</ref>
The [[Revenue Act of 1913]] excluded "labor, agricultural, or horticultural organizations" from income tax liability.<ref name= 501c5/><ref>Tariff Act of 1913, ch. 16, § 11(G), 38 Stat. 172.</ref>
===Contributions and activities=== Much like 501(c)(4) and 501(c)(6) organizations, 501(c)(5) organizations may also perform some political activities.<ref name= lobbyinglaw>{{cite news |title= The Lobbying Law Is More Charitable Than They Think |last= Berry |first= Jeffrey M. |work= The Washington Post |date= November 30, 2003 |page= B1 |url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/409584752/ }}</ref> 501(c)(5) organizations are allowed to [[lobbying in the United States|attempt to influence legislation]] that is related to the common union interests of its members.<ref name= rev-rul-61-177>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr61-177.pdf Rev. Rul. 61-177, 1961-2 C.B. 117]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1961.</ref>
501(c)(5) organizations can receive unlimited contributions from corporations, individuals, and labor unions. The names and addresses of contributors are not required to be made available for public inspection.<ref name="schedule b general">"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f990ezb.pdf Form 990, Schedule B: Schedule of Contributors: General Instructions]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 2015.</ref> All other information, including the amount of contributions, the description of noncash contributions, and any other information, is required to be made available for public inspection unless it clearly identifies the contributor.
A union membership dues paid to a 501(c)(5) organization are generally an ordinary and necessary business expense.<ref name= 1.162-15>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/1.162-15 Rev. Rul. 1.162-15(c)]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1965.</ref> The membership dues are tax-deductible in full unless a substantial part of the 501(c)(5) organization's activities consists of political activity, in which case a tax deduction is allowed only for the portion of membership dues that are for other activities.<ref name= 1.162-15/>
Because associations involved in fishing and seafood harvesting were having difficulties qualifying for reduced postal rates,<ref>S. Rep. No. 94-938 at 419, 420, reprinted in 1976-3 C.B. (vol. 3) 457-458.</ref> in 1976 Congress established Internal Revenue Code Section 501(5) to define "agriculture" as the art or science of cultivating land, harvesting crops or aquatic resources, or raising livestock.<ref name= 501c5/>
Every organization, including a 501(c)(5) organization, that [[independent expenditure|expressly advocates for the election or defeat of a particular political candidate]] and spends more than $250 during a calendar year must disclose the name of each person who contributed more than $200 during the calendar year to the [[Federal Election Commission]].<ref name= fec1/><ref name= fec3/> The Federal Election Commission is required to enforce this provision based on a [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|federal court]] decision in 2018.<ref name= fec2/><ref name= fec4/><ref name= fec3/>
==501(c)(6)== A '''501(c)(6) organization''' is a business league, chambers of commerce like the [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]], a real estate board, a board of trade, a professional football league or an organization like the [[Edison Electric Institute]] and the [[Security Industry Association]], that are not organized for profit and no part of the net earnings goes to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual.<ref name = irs-501c6>Reilly, John Francis; Hull, Carter C.; Braig Allen, Barbara A. "[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopick03.pdf IRC 501(c)(6) Organizations]". ''Exempt Organizations-Technical Instruction Program for FY 2003 ''. Internal Revenue Service. 2003.</ref>
===Qualifications for exemption=== A business league may qualify if it is an association of persons having a common business interest, whose purpose is to promote the common business interest and whose activities improve business conditions rather than actually conduct the business itself.<ref>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/1.501(c)(6)-1 26 CFR 1.501(c)(6)-1 - Business leagues, chambers of commerce, real estate boards, and boards of trade]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Legal Information Institute. Cornell University Law School.</ref> Members of the organization must be of the same trade, business, occupation, or profession in order to qualify.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr59-391.pdf Rev. Rul. 59-391, 1959-2 C.B. 151]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1959.</ref> A chamber of commerce or board of trade could qualify for similar reasons except that they may promote the common economic interests of all the commercial enterprises in a given trade or community.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr73-411.pdf Rev. Rul. 73-411, 1973-2 C.B. 180]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1973.</ref>
An association would not qualify if its principal activities consist of securing benefits and performing particular services for members.<ref>American Automobile Association v. Commissioner, 19 T.C. 1146 (1953).</ref>
An association that promotes the common interests of certain hobbyists would not qualify because the Internal Revenue Service does not consider hobbies to be activities conducted as businesses.<ref>American Kennel Club v. Hoey, 142 F.2d 920 (2nd Cir. 1945).</ref>
An organization whose primary activity is advertising the products or services of its members does not qualify because the organization is performing a service for its members rather than promoting common interests.<ref>Automotive Electric Association v. Commissioner, 168 F.2d 366 (6th Cir. 1948).</ref><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr64-315.pdf Rev. Rul. 64-315, 1964-2 C.B. 147]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1964.</ref> If an organization's primary activity is advertising the products or services of its members' industry as a whole, however, the organization will generally qualify if it also performs other services for its members.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr55-444.pdf Rev. Rul. 55-444, 1955-2, C.B. 258]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1955.</ref>
===Contributions and activities=== Much like 501(c)(4) and 501(c)(5) organizations, 501(c)(6) organizations may also perform some political activities.<ref name= lobbyinglaw></ref> 501(c)(6) organizations are allowed to [[lobbying in the United States|attempt to influence legislation]] that is related to the common business interests of its members.<ref name= rev-rul-61-177></ref>
A 501(c)(6) organization may receive unlimited contributions from corporations, individuals, and labor unions. The names and addresses of contributors are not required to be made available for public inspection,<ref name="schedule b general"></ref> with the exception of a 501(c)(6) organization that makes [[independent expenditure]]s.<ref name= fec1/><ref name= fec2/><ref name= fec3/><ref name= fec4/> All other information, including the amount of contributions, the description of non-cash contributions, and any other information, is required to be made available for public inspection unless it clearly identifies the contributor. The [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]] is a large political spender, and [[Freedom Partners]] used its status as a 501(c)(6) organization to raise and distribute over $250 million during the [[United States presidential election, 2012#Campaigns|2012 election campaigns]] without disclosing its donors.<ref name="freedom-partners">{{cite news| author1= Mike Allen | author2= Jim Vandehei |title = The Koch brothers' secret bank| url= http://www.politico.com/story/2013/09/behind-the-curtain-exclusive-the-koch-brothers-secret-bank-96669.html|accessdate=29 November 2013| work = [[Politico]] |date=11 September 2013}}</ref> The group's existence was not publicly known until nearly a year after the election.
A business' membership dues paid to a 501(c)(6) organization are generally an ordinary and necessary business expense.<ref name= 1.162-15></ref> The membership dues are tax-deductible in full unless a substantial part of the 501(c)(6) organization's activities consists of political activity, in which case a tax deduction is allowed only for the portion of membership dues that are for other activities.<ref name= 1.162-15/>
Every organization, including a 501(c)(6) organization, that [[independent expenditure|expressly advocates for the election or defeat of a particular political candidate]] and spends more than $250 during a calendar year must disclose the name of each person who contributed more than $200 during the calendar year to the [[Federal Election Commission]].<ref name= fec1/><ref name= fec3/> The Federal Election Commission is required to enforce this provision based on a [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|federal court]] decision in 2018.<ref name= fec2/><ref name= fec4/><ref name= fec3/>
===History=== The predecessor of IRC 501(c)(6) was enacted as part of the [[Revenue Act of 1913]]<ref name= 16IIGa>[[Revenue Act of 1913|Tariff Act of 1913]], ch.16, § II (G)(a), 38 Stat. 72."[[Revenue Act of 1913|Tariff Act of 1913]], ch.16, § II (G)(a), 38 Stat. 72. "...nothing this section shall apply to labor, agricultural, or horticultural organizations, or to mutual savings banks not having a capital stock represented by shares, or to fraternal beneficiary societies, orders, or associations operating under the lodge system or for the exclusive benefit of the members of a fraternity itself operating under the lodge system, and providing for the payment of life, sick, accident, and other benefits to the members of such societies, orders, or associations and dependents of such members, nor to domestic building and loan associations, nor to cemetery companies, organized and operated exclusively for the mutual benefit of their members, nor to any corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, or educational purposes, no part of the net income of which inures to the benefit of any private stockholder or individual, nor to business leagues, nor to chambers of commerce or boards of trade, not organized for profit or no part of the net income of which inures to the benefit of the private stockholder or individual ; nor to any civic league or organization not organized for profit, but operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare.</ref> likely due to a U.S. Chamber of Commerce request for an exemption for nonprofit "civic" and "commercial" organizations, which resulted in IRC 501(c)(4) for nonprofit "civic" organizations and IRC 501(c)(6) for nonprofit "commercially-oriented" organizations.<ref name= irs-501c6/> The [[Revenue Act of 1928]] amended the statute to include real estate boards.<ref>Rev. Act of 1928, ch. 852, § 103(7), 48 Stat. 700.</ref> In 1966, professional football leagues were added to the described organizations.<ref>Act of Nov. 8, 1966, Pub. L. 89- 800, § 6(a), 80 Stat. 1515.</ref>
The Revenue Act of 1913 related to professional football leagues had both antitrust and tax provisions: The antitrust provision was enacted to permit the merger of the [[National Football League|National]] and [[American Football League]]s to go forward without fear of an antitrust challenge under either the 1914 [[Clayton Antitrust Act]] or the 1914 [[Federal Trade Commission Act]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reilly|first1=John Francis | last2 = Hull | first2 =Carter C.| last3=Braig Allen| first3=Barbara |title=Exempt Organizations: Technical Instruction Program for FY 2003 IRC 501(c)(6) Organizations |url = https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopick03.pdf |publisher=IRS|accessdate=1 June 2014|date=2003}}</ref> IRC 501(c)(6) amendment was enacted in 1966 to ensure that a professional football league's exemption would not be jeopardized because it administered a players' pension fund.<ref>H.R. Conf. Rept. No 2308, 89th Cong., 2d Sess. (1966), reprinted in 1966-2 C.B. 958, 963, 964.</ref> Additionally, a professional sports league's exemption is not to be jeopardized because its primary source of revenue is the sale of television broadcasting rights to its games because the broadcasting of games increases public awareness of the sport.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr58-502.pdf Rev. Rul. 58-502, 1958-2 C.B. 271]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1958.</ref><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr80-294.pdf Rev. Rul. 80-294, 1980-2 C.B. 187]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1980.</ref>
In 2013, [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Tom Coburn]] introduced legislation to disallow a tax exemption for the [[National Football League]], the [[Professional Golfers' Association]], and other professional sports organizations.<ref name= architect>{{cite news |title= The real architect of NFL's big profits |last= Kang |first= Cecilia |work= The Washington Post |date= September 17, 2014 |page= A12 |url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/1562299916/ }}</ref><ref name= helps>{{cite news |title= How the government helps the NFL maintain its power and profitability |last= Kang |first= Cecilia |work= The Washington Post |date= September 17, 2014 |url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/1562987251/ }}</ref> Coburn estimated the tax exemption cost $100 million, but he said he could not get other members of Congress to support the legislation.<ref name= architect/><ref name= helps/>
==501(c)(7)== A '''501(c)(7) organization''' is a [[social club|social or recreational club]] that is organized for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes.<ref name= 501c7eo>Langley, Jim; Rosenberg, Conrad. "[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicc96.pdf C. Social Clubs - IRC 501(c)(7)]". ''1996 Exempt Organization Continuing Professional Education Text''. Internal Revenue Service. 1996.</ref> Members must share interests and have a common goal directed toward pleasure and recreation, and the organization must provide opportunities for personal contact among members.<ref name= personalcontact>"[https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/other-non-profits/social-clubs-requirements-for-exemption-personal-contact-required Social Clubs – Requirements for Exemption – Personal Contact Required]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. December 9, 2015.</ref><ref>"[http://www.irsvideos.gov/StartingOffRightNON501c3/player/Powerpoint_Slide_Presentation_with_Transcript.pdf Starting Off Right: What New Non- 501(c)(3) Organizations Need to Know]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. February 24, 2010.</ref> The organization's facilities and services must be open to its members and their guests only.<ref>Sullivan, Denise. "[http://smallbusiness.chron.com/501-c-7-corporation-56453.html What is a 501(c)(7) Corporation?]" ''The Houston Chronicle''. 2013.</ref> The organization must be a club of individuals, and no individual may derive profit from the organization's net earnings.<ref name= venable>Tenenbaum, Jeffrey S.; Journy, Matthew T. "[https://www.venable.com/requirements-for-tax-exempt-status-under-irc--501c7-a-primer-for-social-clubs-06-03-2008/ Requirements for Tax-Exempt Status under IRC § 501(c)(7): A Primer for Social Clubs]". ''[[Venable LLP]]''. June 2008.</ref> Examples include [[alumni association|college alumni association]]s; [[Fraternities and sororities|college fraternities or college sororities]] operating chapter houses for students; [[country club]]s; [[amateur sports|amateur sport clubs]]; [[supper club]]s that provide a meeting place, library, and dining room for members; [[hobby|hobby club]]s; and [[garden club]]s.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/publications/p557/ch04.html#en_US_201602_publink1000200325 Publication 557: Tax Exempt Status for Your Organization]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Retrieved August 5, 2016.</ref>
===Activities=== A substantial amount of the 501(c)(7) organization's activities must be related to social and recreational activities for its members.<ref name= 501c7-1976>S. Rep. No. 94-1318, 94th Cong., 2nd Sess. 4 (1976), 1976-2 C.B. 597, 599.</ref> No more than 35 percent of its gross receipts may derive from non-members, and no more than 15 percent of its gross receipts is permitted to come from use of its facilities or services by the general public.<ref name= 501c7eo/> An organization that exceeds these limits may lose its 501(c)(7) status.<ref name= 501c7eo1990>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopich90.pdf H. Nonmember Income of Social, Fraternal, Veterans, and Social Welfare Organizations]". ''1990 Exempt Organization Continuing Professional Education Text''. Internal Revenue Service. 1990.</ref>
When a group of eight or fewer individuals, at least one of whom is a member, uses the organization's facilities and the member pays for the other individuals, the Internal Revenue Service will assume the nonmembers are the guests of the member, and the revenue is deemed to be derived from the member.<ref name= venable/> Similarly, if at least 75 percent a group using club facilities are members of the organization, the Internal Revenue Service will assume the nonmembers are the guests of the member, and the revenue is deemed to be derived from the member.<ref name= venable/> It is the responsibility of the organization to maintain these records.<ref name= 501c7eo1990/> If the organization does not keep sufficient records to link revenue to a member, the Internal Revenue Service assumes the revenue came from a nonmember.<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/irm/part4/irm_04-076-016.html Internal Revenue Manual: Part 4 Examining Process: Chapter 76 Exempt Organizations Examination Guidelines: Section 16 Social and Recreational Clubs - IRC §501(c)(7)]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Retrieved August 5, 2016.</ref>
The organization is subject to unrelated business income tax for the revenue derived from nonmember use of its facilities and services, less allowable deductions.<ref name= 501c7eo1990/> If the organization sells assets that were previously used for recreational or social purposes, the proceeds are not considered unrelated business income as long as the proceeds are reinvested in the organization.<ref>"[http://www.cmaa.org/uploadedFiles/For_Members/Economy/501c7Checklist.pdf http://www.cmaa.org/uploadedFiles/For_Members/Economy/501c7Checklist.pdf Club Tax Book]". ''Mitchell L. Stump, CPA, PA''. Club Managers Association of America. December 2004.</ref>
A 501(c)(7) organization cannot have a policy of discriminating on the basis of race, color, or religion.<ref name= venable/> Nevertheless, a 501(c)(7) organization is permitted to limit its members to a particular religion in order to further the teachings of that religion.<ref name= venable/> An auxiliary of a 501(c)(8) fraternal benefit society that limits membership to members of a particular religion is allowed to do so as well.<ref name= venable/> The Internal Revenue Service has determined that 501(c)(7) are not prohibited from discriminating against ethnic groups.<ref name= venable/>
===Donations=== An individual's donation to a fraternity is only a tax-deductible charitable contribution if the contribution "is to be used exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, literary, or educational purposes, or for the prevention of cruelty to children or animals."<ref>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/170 Internal Revenue Code Section 170(c)(4)]". ''Legal Information Institute''. Cornell University Law School. Retrieved May 21, 2017.</ref>
===History=== The predecessor of Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(7) was part of the [[Revenue Act of 1913]], which provides a tax-exemption to "fraternal beneficiary societies, orders, or associations operating under the lodge system or for the exclusive benefit of the members of a fraternity itself operating under the lodge system".<ref name= 16IIGa/> Congress justified the tax-exemption with the reasoning that the members join together to provide themselves with recreational or social organization without further tax consequences, similar as if they had paid for the benefits directly.<ref name = 501c7eo/> Tax-exemption was available for organizations operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes.<ref name= 501c7eo/>
In 1969, Congress passed a law stating that social and recreational clubs were permitted to engage in some unrelated business income, subject to income tax.<ref name= 501c7eo/>
==501(c)(8)== A '''501(c)(8) organization''' is a [[benefit society|fraternal benefit society]].<ref name= 501c8-eo>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicf04.pdf IRC 501(cc)(8) Fraternal Beneficiary Societies and IRC 501(c)(10) Domestic Fraternal Societies]". ''2004 EO CPE Text''. Internal Revenue Service. 2004.</ref>
===Eligibility=== The society must have members of a similar calling, recreation, or profession, or members who work together to accomplish a worthy goal.<ref name= nationalunion>National Union v. Marlow, 74 F. 775, 778-79 (8th Cir. 1896).</ref> The members have associated themselves in order to help each other and to promote the common cause.<ref name= nationalunion/> The society must have written documentation of its eligibility standards for membership, classes of membership, a process of admission, and rights and privileges of members.<ref>"[http://www.fraternalalliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/1983-NFCA-Model-Fraternal-Code.pdf Modern Fraternal Code Section 6]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}".</ref>
The members must have a common bond, which may be based on religious beliefs, gender, occupation, ethnicity, or shared values.<ref name= afa>"[https://netforum.avectra.com/eWeb/DynamicPage.aspx?Site=afalliance&WebCode=FraternalSociety What is a Fraternal Benefit Society?]" ''American Fraternal Alliance''. Retrieved August 26, 2016.</ref>
The society must have a supreme governing body and subordinate lodges into which members are elected, initiated, or admitted in accordance with its laws.<ref name= 501c8-eo/> The supreme governing body should be composed of delegates elected directly by members or intermediate assemblies.<ref name= 501c8-eo/>
The society must offer benefits to members, which may include life insurance, medical insurance, scholarships, educational programs, travel opportunities, and discount programs.<ref name= afa/> Revenue generated from providing benefits to non-members must be insubstantial to the society and may be taxable as [[unrelated business income]].<ref>GCM 38312 (Mar. 20, 1980).</ref>
===History=== Fraternal benefit societies trace their lineage back through [[mutual benefit]] societies, [[friendly societies]] and eventually to medieval [[guild]]s.<ref name="ss">{{cite web|url=http://www.ssa.gov/history/briefhistory3.html/ |title=Historical Background and Development of Social Security |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160102072306/https://www.ssa.gov/history/briefhistory3.html |archivedate=2 January 2016 }}</ref> Many fraternal benefit societies were founded to serve the needs of immigrants and other under-served groups<ref>{{cite book | title = Statistics of Fraternal Benefit Societies, 117th Edition (2011); American Fraternal Alliance, p. iv. }}</ref> who shared common bonds of religion, ethnicity, gender, occupation or shared values.
Section 38 of the [[Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act|Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act of 1909]] was the first law to provide a tax-exemption for fraternal beneficiary societies.<ref>Revenue Act of 1913. Pub. L. No. 63-6. Section II(G)(a). 38 Stat. 172.</ref> The tax-exemption was later codified as section 501(c)(8) with the [[Internal Revenue Code of 1954]].<ref name= 501c8-irs>"[https://www.irs.gov/irm/part7/irm_07-025-008.html 7.25.8 Fraternal Beneficiary Societies]". ''Internal Revenue Manual''. Internal Revenue Service. Retrieved August 26, 2016.</ref>
==501(c)(13)== A '''501(c)(13)''' organization is a certain type of cemetery company.
===Eligibility=== There are two primary types of eligible cemetery companies. A mutual cemetery company must be either "owned by and operated exclusively for the benefit of its lot owners who hold such lots for bona fide burial purposes and not for the purpose of fesale" or engages in the burial of impoverished people performing similar charitable activities.<ref name= 1501c13-1>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/26/1.501%28c%29%2813%29-1 § 1.501(c)(13)-1]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Legal Information Institute. Cornell University Law School. Retrieved October 19, 2018.</ref> A nonprofit cemetery corporation must be incorporated solely for the purpose of the burial or the cremation of bodies and no part of its net earnings inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual.<ref name= 1501c13-1/> Any net gain by the cemetery must be devoted to certain cemetery functions, such as the cemetery's operations, maintenance, and improvements; acquisition of cemetery property; and investment of the net gain in order to provide additional income for cemetery functions.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/eotopicj80.pdf Cemeteries]". ''Exempt Organization Continuing Professional Education Texas''. Internal Revenue Service. 1980.</ref> Net gains are not allowed to be distributed to individuals.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/>
The cemetery may restrict burials and cremations to a certain group of people, such as impoverished people, people adherent to a certain religion, or people who lived in a certain community, as long as it still serves a broad class of people and operates for public purposes, but a 501(c)(13) organization may not enforce overly restrictive restrictions.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr78-143.pdf Rev. Rul. 78-143, 1978-1 C.B. 162]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1978.</ref>
A perpetual care fund that is used by a profit-making cemetery to maintain cemetery properties and burial lots is not eligible under 501(c)(13).<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr64-217.pdf Rev. Rul. 64-217, 1964-2 C.B. 153]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1964.</ref> On the other hand, a nonprofit organization may have a perpetual care fund without jeopardizing its exemption under Section 501(c)(13).<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/>
A cemetery that owns or operates a [[morgue]], whether on its own grounds or elsewhere, is not eligible under 501(c)(13) because the Internal Revenue Service does not consider mortuary services necessarily incident to burial purposes.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/><ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr64-109.pdf Rev. Rul. 64-109, 1964-1 C.B. 190]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1964.</ref> The provision of traditional burial services that directly support and maintain basic tenets and beliefs of a religion regarding burial of its members" may still be eligible under 501(c)(13).<ref>"Rev. Rul. 79-359, 1979-45 I.R.B. 10". Internal Revenue Service. 1979.</ref>
A cemetery that buries animals is not eligible under 501(c)(13).<ref>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr73-454.pdf Rev. Rul. 73-454, 1973-2 C.B. 185]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1973.</ref>
A cemetery company wishing to be recognized under Section 501(c)(13) needs to prepare and file Form 1024 with the Internal Revenue Service.<ref>"[https://taxmap.irs.gov/taxmap/pubs/p557-031.htm Publication 557]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. p. 54. Retrieved October 19, 2018.</ref>
===Charitable contributions=== Charitable contributions to a 501(c)(13) organization are tax-deductible to the donor.<ref>"[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/170 Internal Revenue Code Section 170(c)(5)]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. Legal Information Institute. Cornell University Law School. Retrieved October 19, 2018.</ref> Payments for perpetual care of a particular lot or a particular crypt are not considered tax-deductible charitable contributions.<ref name= revrul-58-190>"[https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-tege/rr58-190.pdf Rev. Rul. 58-190, 1958-1 C.B. 15]". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1958.</ref> Payments made as part of the purchase price of a burial lot or crypt are not considered tax-deductible charitable contributions, even if a portion of the payment is for the perpetual care of the entirety of the cemetery.<ref name= revrul-58-190/> Bequests or gifts to a 501(c)(13) cemetery is not deductible for federal estate tax purposes or gift tax purposes.<ref>"Rev. Rul. 67-170, 1967-1 C.B. 272". ''Internal Revenue Service''. 1967.</ref><ref name= irs-eo-501c13/>
===History=== Historically, cemeteries were exempt from local property taxes and excise taxes in most states because states generally considered cemeteries to be performing a recognized civic service.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/>
The [[Tariff Act of 1913]] provided an exemption from federal income taxes for mutual cemetery companies that were organized and operated exclusively "for the benefit of their members".<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/> In 1921, Congress extended the tax-exemption to cemetery companies that are not mutual and to cemetery companies that are not operated for profit as well as any corporation solely incorporated to operate a cemetery and whose net gains do not inure to any person.<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/>
In 1970, Congress included crematorium in the definition of cemetery for the purposes of Section 501(c)(13).<ref name= irs-eo-501c13/><ref>"P.L. 91-618 (84 Stat. 1955)".</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox court case | name = A v SS for Home Department | court = House of Lords | image = HMP Belmarsh, from carpark.jpg | date decided = | full name = A and others v Secretary of State for the Home Department; X and another v Secretary of State for the Home Department | citations = [2004] UKHL 56 | judges = | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | keywords = Indefinite detention, right to trial }}
'''''A and others v Secretary of State for the Home Department''''' [2004] UKHL 56 (also known as the '''''Belmarsh 9''''' case) is a [[UK human rights]] case heard before the [[Appellate Committee of the House of Lords|House of Lords]]. It held that the indefinite detention of foreign prisoners in [[Belmarsh (HM Prison)|Belmarsh]] without trial under section 23 of the [[Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001]] was [[declaration of incompatibility|incompatible]] with the [[European Convention on Human Rights]].
The case should not be confused with the case ''[[A v Secretary of State for the Home Department (No 2)]]'' [2005] UKHL 71, which relates to the use of evidence obtained by torture in British courts.
==Facts== The case began with nine men who challenged a decision of the [[Special Immigration Appeals Commission]] to eject them from the country on the basis that there was evidence that they threatened national security.
Of the nine appellants, all except two were detained in December 2001; the others were detained in February and April 2002 respectively. All were detained under the [[Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001]].<ref name=autogenerated1>http://www.lawbore.net/gotosite.php?id=1009</ref> Part 4 of the Act provided for their indefinite detention without trial and deportation. However, the power was only applied to non-British nationals. Under section 25 of this Act, they had the right to appeal to the [[Special Immigration Appeals Commission]] against their detention.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200506/ldjudgmt/jd051208/aand-1.htm|title=House of Lords - A (FC) and others (FC) (Appellants) v. Secretary of State for the Home Department (Respondent) (2004)A and others (Appellants) (FC) and others v. Secretary of State for the Home Department (Respondent) (Conjoined Appeals)|first=Law Lords|last=Department|website=publications.parliament.uk}}</ref>
==Judgment== The House of Lords held by a majority ([[Lord Bingham of Cornhill]], [[Lord Nicholls of Birkenhead]], [[David Hope, Baron Hope of Craighead|Lord Hope of Craighead]], [[Lord Scott of Foscote]], [[Alan Rodger, Baron Rodger of Earlsferry|Lord Rodger of Earlsferry]], [[Baroness Hale of Richmond]] and [[Lord Carswell]]) that, whilst their detention was lawful under the ATCSA 2001, section 23 was incompatible with the articles of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. As a consequence, the House of Lords made a declaration of incompatibility under section 4 of the Human Rights Act 1998, and allowed the appeals.
[[Lord Hoffmann]] dissented in strong terms, but agreed that the appeals should be allowed. Whereas the majority argued that the 2001 Act was contrary to the ECHR because it discriminated between nationals and foreign nationals (Art.14 ECHR), Lord Hoffmann stated that the whole scheme was incompatible with the United Kingdom's constitution, and its commitment to human rights. He dismissed the government's argument that under the ECHR and HRA it was possible to derogate from the ECHR's general provisions. His view was that the test – that there was a "threat to the life of the nation" – was not fulfilled.
{{quote|{{ordered list| start=96| This is a nation which has been tested in adversity, which has survived physical destruction and catastrophic loss of life. I do not underestimate the ability of fanatical groups of terrorists to kill and destroy, but they do not threaten the life of the nation. Whether we would survive [[Hitler]] hung in the balance, but there is no doubt that we shall survive Al-Qaeda. The Spanish people have not said that what happened in Madrid, hideous crime as it was, threatened the life of their nation. Their legendary pride would not allow it. Terrorist violence, serious as it is, does not threaten our institutions of government or our existence as a civil community. | For these reasons I think that the [[Special Immigration Appeals Commission]] made an error of law and that the appeal ought to be allowed. Others of your Lordships who are also in favour of allowing the appeal would do so, not because there is no emergency threatening the life of the nation, but on the ground that a power of detention confined to foreigners is irrational and discriminatory. I would prefer not to express a view on this point. I said that the power of detention is at present confined to foreigners and I would not like to give the impression that all that was necessary was to extend the power to United Kingdom citizens as well. In my opinion, such a power in any form is not compatible with our constitution. The real threat to the life of the nation, in the sense of a people living in accordance with its traditional laws and political values, comes not from terrorism but from laws such as these. That is the true measure of what terrorism may achieve. It is for Parliament to decide whether to give the terrorists such a victory.}}}}
Lord Walker of Gestingthorpe also dissented, but would have dismissed the appeal. In his opinion, the discrimination was justified due to "sound, rational grounds for different treatment". While the indefinite detention provisions were a "grave concern", they were "necessary" and accompanied by "several important safeguards against oppression". He therefore held that Part 4 of the 2001 Act was "proportionate, rational and non-discriminatory".
==Significance== Parliament decided to replace Part 4 of ATCSA 2001 with the [[Prevention of Terrorism Act 2005]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> This allows anyone of any nationality to be subjected to a [[control order]].
==Notes==
<references /> * ''[http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/2004/56.html A v Secretary of State for the Home Department ]''[http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/2004/56.html [2004] UKHL 56], on whether persons can be detained indefinitely without reasons being given for that detention.
==External links== * [https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200405/ldjudgmt/jd041216/a&others.pdf full text of decision]
