'''First Family''' is an unofficial title for the [[family]] of a [[republic]]'s [[head of state]]. A First Family usually consists of: the head of state, the [[first spouse]] and their children.
==Related terms== The term ''Second Family'' is often used to refer to the deputy head of state, usually a [[vice-president]], or, in some countries, the family of the prime minister, in deference to a first family or [[royal family]].{{fact|date=October 2015}} The spouse is called the ''Second Lady'' or ''Second Gentleman''.
==In popular culture== The use of the term "First Family" to refer to the family of the President of the United States only came into widespread use during the Kennedy administration with the tremendous popularity of [[Vaughn Meader]]'s 1962 comedy album, ''The First Family."<ref name="NoticeOfPOTUS">{{cite news|title=Taking Notice of POTUS|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1997/10/taking-notice-of-potus/376985/|accessdate=25 January 2017|publisher=The Atlantic|date=October 1997}}</ref>
===Comics=== *In the comic book series ''[[Astro City]]'', the First Family is a family of super-powered adventurers whose actual surname is "Furst."
===Film=== *[[Bob Newhart]] played an unpopular [[President of the United States]] in the 1980 movie ''[[First Family (film)|First Family]]''.
===Literature === *''First Family (King and Maxwell)'' (2010) is a novel by [[David Baldacci]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Baldacci, David|title=First Family (King and Maxwell)|publisher=Grand Central Publishing; Reprint edition |date=March 1, 2010|isbn= 0446539740}}</ref> *''The First Family: Terror, Extortion, Revenge, Murder and The Birth of the American Mafia'' (2010) is a nonfiction book by [[Mike Dash]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Dash, Mike|title=The First Family: Terror, Extortion, Revenge, Murder and the Birth of the American Mafia|publisher=Ballantine Books; Reprint edition |date=August 31, 2010|isbn= 0345523571}}</ref> *''First Family'' is the second novel in [[Patrick Tilley]]'s ''[[The Amtrak Wars]]'' series.
===Television=== *In the ''[[Doctor Who]]'', episode "Partners in Crime", the First Family commissioned Miss Foster to create the Adipose. *''[[The First Family (TV Series)|The First Family]]'' is an American sitcom that began airing in first-run syndication in the United States beginning in 2012.
==In fossils== [[AL 333|The First Family]] is also a collection of ''[[Australopithecus afarensis]]'' [[fossils]] discovered at site "333" at [[Hadar, Ethiopia|Hadar]] in [[Ethiopia]], near the location of another famous ''A. afarensis'', [[Lucy (Australopithecus)|Lucy]]. ''A. afarensis'' is believed to be the first habitual bipedal [[Hominidae|hominid]] and a direct ancestor of ''[[Homo sapiens]]''. This species lived between 3.9 million to 2.9 million years ago.
==See also== * [[First Family of the United States]] * [[Royal Family]] in monarchies

A '''food safety agency''' or '''food administration''' is a kind of [[Government agency|agency]] found in various countries and international organizations with responsibilities related to food, primarily with ensuring the safety of food sold or distributed to the population, and with ensuring that food sellers inform the population of the origins and health qualities and risks associated with food being sold.
==Food safety agencies by country==
{{Empty section|date=March 2014}}
==North America==
=== United States === * The [[Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition]], the branch of the United States Food and Drug Administration that regulates food, dietary supplements, and cosmetics * The [[Food and Drug Administration (United States)]], an agency of the United States Department of Health and Human Services responsible for protecting and promoting public health through the regulation and supervision of food safety, tobacco products, dietary supplements, medications, vaccines, biopharmaceuticals, blood transfusions, medical devices, electromagnetic radiation emitting devices, veterinary products, and cosmetics * The [[Food Safety Commission]], a commission directed in 2002 to be established in the United States to report to the President and Congress on enhancing the food safety system * The [[United States Food Administration]], the responsible agency for the administration of the Allies' food reserves during the United States' participation in World War I
==South America==
=== Argentina === * The [[National Food Safety and Quality Service]], an independent agency of the Argentine government
==Asia==
===People's Republic of China=== The [[State Food and Drug Administration]], the agency of the government of the People{{'}}s Republic of China in charge of comprehensive supervision of the safety management of food, health food, and cosmetics, and the competent authority for drug regulation
=== Singapore === In Singapore Food Administration in terms of [[Food safety]] is controlled for the [[Gastronomy in Singapore]] by the [[National Environment Agency]] (NEA). Goods which are imported/exported to the [[Little red dot]] are regulated/controlled by [[Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore]] (AVA).
=== India === '''[[Food Safety and Standards Authority of India]] (FSSAI)''' is an autonomous body established under the [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India)|Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Government of India]]. The organisation is responsible for protecting and promoting [[public health]] through the [[regulation]] and supervision of [[food safety]]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fssai.gov.in/AboutFSSAI/introduction.aspx|title=Food Safety and Standards Authority of India|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Australia and New Zealand == * The [[Food Standards Australia New Zealand]], the governmental body responsible for developing food standards for Australia and New Zealand * The [[New Zealand Food Safety Authority]], the New Zealand government body responsible for food safety and the controlling authority for imports and exports of food and food-related products
==Europe==
=== European Parliament and European Union === * The [[Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety]], a committee of the European Parliament responsible for environmental policy and environmental protection measures, public health, and food safety issues * The [[European Food Safety Authority]], an agency of the European Union that provides independent scientific advice and communication on existing and emerging risks associated with the food chain
=== Ireland and Northern Ireland === * The [[Food Safety Authority of Ireland]] is responsible for the enforcement of food safety regulations and standards in the Republic of Ireland * The UK [[Food Standards Agency]] has jurisdiction in Northern Ireland * The [[Food Safety Promotion Board]], the body responsible for the promotion of food safety in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland
=== Netherlands === * The [[Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (Netherlands)]], a ministry of the government of the Netherlands responsible for agriculture, fisheries, natural conservation, open-air recreation and national parks, food safety, and rural development
=== Norway === * The [[Norwegian Food Safety Authority]], a Norwegian government agency responsible for safe food and drinking water; human, plant, fish, and animal health; environmentally friendly production and ethically acceptable farming of animals; cosmetics; medicines; and the inspection of animal health personnel
=== Sweden === * The [[National Food Administration (Sweden)]], a Swedish government agency that is the central supervisory authority for matters relating to food and drinking water
=== United Kingdom === * The [[Food Standards Agency]], a non-ministerial department of the Government of the United Kingdom responsible for protecting public health in relation to food
== United Nations and World Health Organization == * The [[Joint FAO/WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives]], a scientific expert committee jointly run by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Health Organization
== See also == * [[Agriculture ministry]], a ministry or other government agency charged with agriculture. The ministry is often headed by a minister for agriculture * [[Fisheries management]], draws on fisheries science in order to find ways to protect fishery resources so sustainable exploitation is possible * [[Food quality]], the quality characteristics of food that is acceptable to consumers * [[Food safety]], a scientific discipline describing handling, preparation, and storage of food in ways that prevent foodborne illness * [[List of non-profit food safety organisations]]
==References== <references />

{{distinguish|Austrian nationalism}} {{good article}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} [[File:Kornblume.jpeg|thumb|250px|A blue [[Centaurea cyanus|cornflower]], the symbol of the pan-Germanist movement in Austria]]
'''German nationalism''' ({{lang-de|Deutschnationalismus}}) is a political ideology and historical current in [[politics of Austria|Austrian politics]]. It arose in the 19th century as a [[nationalist]] movement amongst the German-speaking population of the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]]. It favours close ties with Germany, which it views as the nation-state for all [[ethnic Germans]], and the possibility of the incorporation of Austria into a [[German question|Greater Germany]].
Over the course of Austrian history, from the [[Austrian Empire]], to [[Austria-Hungary]], and the [[Republic of Austria (1919–1934)|First]] and the [[Second Austrian Republic|Second]] Austrian Republics, several political parties and groups have expressed pan-German nationalist sentiment. [[National liberalism|National liberal]] and pan-Germanist parties have been termed the "Third Camp" ({{lang-de|Drittes Lager}}) of Austrian politics, as they have traditionally been ranked behind mainstream Catholic conservatives and socialists.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Stephan |last=Kamps |title=Die Freiheitlichen – Nazistische Reinkarnation oder politische Erneuerung? |publisher=GRIN Verlag |year=2007 |language=German |pages=27–31 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k_QT85LZB0oC&pg=PA30 |isbn=9783638715454 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |first=Richard |last=Voithofer |title=Drum schliesst Euch frisch an Deutschland an .. |publisher=Böhlau Verlag |year=2000 |language=German |page=17 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l_epwaB5q98C&pg=PA57 |isbn=9783205992226 }}</ref> The [[Freedom Party of Austria]], a [[far-right]] political party with representation in the [[Austrian parliament]], has pan-Germanist roots.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Anton |last=Pelinka |authorlink=Anton Pelinka |title=Jörg Haiders "Freiheitliche" – ein nicht nur österreichisches Problem |work=Liberalismus in Geschichte und Gegenwart |publisher=Königshausen & Neumann |year=2000 |language=German |page=233 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NWmudq4s4GAC&pg=PA233 |isbn=9783826015540 }}</ref> After the [[Second World War]], both pan-Germanism and the idea of [[Anschluss|political union with Germany]] were discredited by their association with [[Nazism]], and by the rising tide of a civic [[Austrians|Austrian national identity]].
==During the imperial period== [[File:Deutscher Schulverein.jpg|thumb|''"And the German spirit will once again heal the world"'' – A pan-Germanist [[postal stamp|stamp]] of the German School League]] Within the context of rising ethnic nationalism during the 19th century in the territories of the multi-ethnic Austrian Empire, the "German National Movement" ({{lang-de|Deutschnationale Bewegung}}) sought the creation of a [[Greater Germany]], along with the implementation of [[Antisemitism|anti-semitic]] and [[Anti-clericalism|anti-clerical]] policies, in an attempt to entrench the German ethnic identity.<ref name="DPSO">{{cite web | url=http://www.politischebildung.at/upload/polsystem.pdf | title=Das politische System in Österreich (The Political System in Austria) | publisher=Austrian Federal Press Service | date=2000 | accessdate=9 July 2014 | page=24 | language=German | location=Vienna}}</ref> Starting with the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire|revolutions of 1848]], many ethnic groups under imperial rule, including the Serbs, Czechs, Italians, Croats, Slovenes, and Poles, amongst others, demanded political, economic, and cultural equality. Traditionally, the German-speaking population of the Empire enjoyed societal privileges dating back to the reign of Empress [[Maria Theresa]], and that of her son, [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]]. German was considered the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of the Empire, and Empire's elite consisted primarily of German-speakers.<ref name="DIa">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=fKpnAAAAMAAJ&q=isbn:0582353939&dq=isbn:0582353939 | title=The Dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, 1867–1918 | publisher=Longman | author=John W. Mason | year=1985 | location=Hong Kong | page=10 | isbn=0-582-35393-9}}</ref><ref name="hm">{{cite book | title=The Habsburg monarchy, 1809–1918: a history of the Austrian Empire and Austria-Hungary | publisher=University of Chicago Press | author=[[A. J. P. Taylor]] | year=1976 | location=Chicago | isbn=0-226-79145-9|page=16|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LMXfMoiI2FgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0226791459#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The struggle between the many ethnic groups of the Empire and German-speakers defined the social and political landscape of the Empire from the 1870s, after the [[Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867|Compromise of 1867]], which granted renewed sovereignty to the [[Kingdom of Hungary]], until the dissolution of the Empire after the [[First World War]].
After the Austrian defeat in the [[Battle of Königgrätz]] of 1866, and the [[Unification of Germany|unification]] of what was then known as "[[German question|Lesser Germany]]" under [[Prussia]]n stewardship in 1871, the German Austrians in the Austro-Hungarian Empire felt that they had wrongly been excluded from the German [[nation-state]], whilst other ethnicities within the Empire were tearing at its fabric.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Kurt |last=Bauer |title=Nationalsozialismus: Ursprünge, Anfänge, Aufstieg und Fall |publisher=Böhlau Verlag |year=2008 |page=41 |language=German |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n9L1GyROMi0C&pg=PA41 |isbn=9783825230760 }}</ref> Conflict between Germans and Czechs grew particularly tense in 1879, when minister-president [[Eduard Taaffe, 11th Viscount Taaffe|Viscount Taaffe]] did not include the [[German-Liberal Party]] ({{lang-de|Deutschliberale Partei}}) in the government of [[Cisleithania]]. This party was considered the main representative of the German-speaking [[Bourgeoisie|middle class]], and as such, the German National Movement went on to accuse the Party of not fighting for the rights of German-speakers within the Empire. The "German School League" ({{lang-de|Deutscher Schulverein}}) was formed in 1880 to protect German-language schools in parts of the Empire where German speakers were a minority.<ref name="G&E">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IHAcEB8jh1AC |first= Arnold |last=Suppan |title=′Germans′ in the Habsburg Empire: Language, Imperial Ideology, National Identity and Assimilation | work=The Germans and the East | publisher=Purdue University Press | year=2008 | page=171 | isbn=1557534438|editor1-last=Ingrao |editor1-first=Charles W. |editor2-last=Szabo |editor2-first=Franz A. J.}}</ref> It promoted the establishment of German-language schools in communities where public funding was used for non-German schools.
[[File:VonSchoenerer.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Georg von Schönerer: radical pan-Germanist, and founder of the Deutschnationaler Verein (German-National Association)]]
A consortium of German nationalist groups and intellectuals published the [[Linz Program of 1882|Linz Program]] in 1882, which demanded the recognition of German predominance in the Empire, along with the complete [[Germanisation]] of the Empire. This manifesto was signed by the radical German nationalist [[Georg Ritter von Schönerer|Georg von Schönerer]], Vienna's populist, pro-Catholic, and royalist mayor [[Karl Lueger]], and the Jewish [[social democrat]] [[Victor Adler]].<ref name="Bideleux">{{Cite book |first1=Robert |last1=Bideleux |first2=Ian |last2=Jeffries |title=A history of eastern Europe: Crisis and Change |publisher=Routledge |year=1998 |page=355 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IuW7T8wfNGAC&pg=PA355 |isbn=9780415161121 }}</ref> The diverse signatories of the Linz manifesto split ideologically after Schönerer revised it to add an "[[Aryan paragraph]]" in 1885.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Michael |last=Wladika |title=Hitlers Vätergeneration: Die Ursprünge des Nationalsozialismus in der k.u.k. Monarchie |publisher=Böhlau Verlag |year=2005 |language=German |page=157 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hAh8RPuxUEUC&pg=PA38 |isbn=9783205773375 }}</ref>
Schönerer founded the "German-National Association" (Deutschnationaler Verein), and later, in 1891, the "Pan-German Society". He demanded the annexation of all German-speaking territories of [[Austria-Hungary]] to the Prussian-led [[German Empire]] and rejected any form of Austrian pan-ethnic identity. His radical racist German nationalism was especially popular amongst the well-educated [[intelligentsia]]: professors, grammar school teachers, and students. School administrations tried to counteract these sentiments by encouraging civic pride, along with a "[[cult of personality]]" around the [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Emperor]], but these efforts were largely unsuccessful. Vienna mayor Karl Lueger even tried to dismiss all "Schönerians" from city school administrations, but this too failed.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Karl |last=Klambauer |title=(...) ein in begeisterter Verehrung ergebener Unterthan! |work=Der Forschende Blick: Beiträge zur Geschichte Österreichs im 20. Jahrhundert |publisher=Böhlau Verlag |year=2010 |page=70 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=FHRZXKBtTeYC&pg=PA70&dq=deutschnationalismus+in+%C3%B6sterreich#v=onepage&q=deutschnationalismus%20in%20%C3%B6sterreich&f=false |language=German|isbn=9783205784708 }}</ref> National-minded students rather identified with the Prussian-led German Empire than with the multiethnic Dual Monarchy. Many idolised the German chancellor [[Otto von Bismarck]], victor in the Battle of Königgrätz.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Suppan |title=′Germans′ in the Habsburg Empire | work=The Germans and the East | year=2008 | pages=171–172}}</ref>
[[File:Ludwig Grillich7.jpg|thumb|180px|Karl Lueger, an Austrian populist who espoused antisemitic and German nationalist notions]]
Members of the pan-German movement wore blue [[Centaurea cyanus|cornflowers]], known to be the favourite flower of German Emperor [[William I, German Emperor|William I]], in their buttonholes, along with [[cockades]] in the German national colours (black, red, and yellow).<ref>{{Cite book |first=Eva |last=Giloi |title=Monarchy, Myth, and Material Culture in Germany 1750–1950 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2011 |pages=161–162}}</ref> Both symbols were temporarily banned in Austrian schools.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Daniel L. |last=Unowsky |title=The Pomp and Politics of Patriotism: Imperial Celebrations in Habsburg Austria, 1848–1916 |publisher=Purdue University Press |year=2005 |page=157}}</ref> Like Schönerer, many Austrians hoped for an ''[[Anschluss]]'' with Germany.{{sfn|Low|1974|p=14}} However, although many Austrians accepted the ideas of the various pan-German movements and felt part of the German nation, they accepted the existence of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, were loyal to the [[Habsburg dynasty]], and wanted to preserve the sovereignty of Austria.{{sfn|Low|1974|p=15}}
German nationalists protested vehemently against minister-president [[Count Kasimir Felix Badeni|Kasimir Count Badeni]]'s language decree of 1897, which made German and Czech co-official languages in Bohemia and required new government officials to be fluent in both languages. This meant in practice that the civil service would almost exclusively hire Czechs, because most educated Czechs knew German, but not the other way around. The support of [[ultramontanism|ultramontane]] Catholic politicians and clergy for this reform triggered the launch of the "[[Away from Rome]]" ({{lang-de|Los-von-Rom}}) movement, which was initiated by supporters of Schönerer and called on "German" Christians to leave the Roman Catholic Church.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Suppan |title=′Germans′ in the Habsburg Empire | work=The Germans and the East | year=2008 | pages=164, 172}}</ref>
From the 1880s, the pan-Germanist movement was fragmented into several splinter parties and factions. The most radical was the [[German Workers' Party (Austria-Hungary)|German Workers' Party]], formed in 1903, which later transformed into the Austrian wing of the [[Austrian National Socialism|Nazi Party]].<ref name="Dgros">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=yheSqWHjExYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=die+grossen+Erzählungen+der+Politik:+politische+Kultur+und+Parteien+in+Österreich+von+der+Jahrhundertwende+bis+1945#v=onepage&q=die%20grossen%20Erzählungen%20der%20Politik%3A%20politische%20Kultur%20und%20Parteien%20in%20Österreich%20von%20der%20Jahrhundertwende%20bis%201945&f=false | title=Die grossen Erzählungen der Politik: politische Kultur und Parteien in Österreich von der Jahrhundertwende bis 1945 | publisher=Böhlau Verlag Wien | author=Robert Kriechbaumer | year=2001 | isbn=3-205-99400-0 | language=German}}</ref> Other pan-Germanist parties that contested elections during the first decade of the 20th century include the [[German People's Party (Austria)|German People's Party]] and the [[German Radical Party]]. A broad coalition of all ethnic German national and liberal political parties known as the ''[[Deutscher Nationalverband]]'' (lit. German National Association) was formed to contest the [[Cisleithanian legislative election, 1911|1911 election]] to the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Cisleithanian Imperial Council]].<ref name="Dnac">{{cite web | url=http://www.aeiou.at/aeiou.encyclop.d/d331764.htm;internal&action=_setlanguage.action?LANGUAGE=en | title=Deutscher Nationalverband | work=Encyclopedia of Austria | accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref><ref name="NDad">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SFQyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The New Austrian Reichsrath | work=The Nation | date=3 August 1911 | accessdate=28 July 2014 | pages=92–93 | volume=93}}</ref> It went on to gain the most seats in lower house of the Council, the House of Deputies ({{lang-de|Abgeordnetenhaus}}), replacing the previously dominant [[Christian Social Party (Austria)|Christian Social Party]].<ref name="G&E2">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IHAcEB8jh1AC | title=The Germans and the East | publisher=Purdue University Press | year=2008 | pages=165 | isbn=1557534438|editor1-last=Ingrao |editor1-first=Charles W. |editor2-last=Szabo |editor2-first=Franz A. J.}}</ref> Despite this victory, the German National Association was always a very loose coalition with little unity amongst its ranks, and collapsed in 1917 at the height of [[First World War]].<ref name="cosdf">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zIjFoAnV4jgC&pg=PA244&lpg=PA244#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Empire and Identity: Biographies of the Austrian State Problem in the Late Habsburg Empire | publisher=Purdue University Press | author=Fredrik Lindström | year=2008 | pages=244 | isbn=1557534640}}</ref> It disintegrated into seventeen scattered German liberal and national parties.<ref name="Dnac"/> This disintegration, combined with dissolution of Austria-Hungary at the end of the First World War, led to the total fragmentation of pan-Germanist movement.
==Dissolution of Austria-Hungary (1918–1919)== [[File:GermanAustriaMap.png|Areas claimed by the ''Republic of German Austria''. These represent areas of the former Empire with majority-German populations.|left|thumb|400px]] After the end of the [[First World War]], which saw the collapse of the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]], German-speaking parts of the former Empire established a new republic under the name "[[German Austria]]" ({{lang-de|Deutsch-Österreich}}). The republic was proclaimed on the principle of [[self-determination]], which had been enshrined within American president [[Woodrow Wilson]]'s ''[[Fourteen Points]]''.<ref name=bm>{{cite book |last=Prinz |first=Friedrich |language=German|title=Deutsche Geschichte in Osten Europas: Böhmen und Mähren |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Deutsche_Geschichte_im_Osten_Europas_Bö.html?id=MmwjAQAAIAAJ |accessdate= 25 February 2013 |year=1993 |publisher=Wolf Jobst Siedler Verlag GmbH |location=Berlin |isbn=3-88680-200-0 |page=381 |pages=}}</ref> A provisional national assembly was convened on 11 November, at which the Republic of German Austria was proclaimed. The assembly drafted a constitution that stated that "German Austria is a democratic republic" (Article 1) and "German Austria is a component of the German Republic" (Article 2). This phrase referenced the establishment of the [[Weimar Republic]] in the former lands of the [[German Empire]], and intended to unite German-speaking Austrians with the German nation-state, completing the [[Greater Germany]] plan. [[Plebiscite]]s held in [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]] and [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]] yielded majorities of 98% and 99% respectively in favour of unification with Germany.
Despite this, the victors of the First World War, who drafted the [[Treaty of Versailles]] and the [[Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1919)|Saint-Germain-en-Laye]], strictly forbid any attempt by German Austria to unify with Germany.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/other/dfat/treaties/1920/3.html |title=Treaty of Peace between the Allied and Associated Powers and Austria; Protocol, Declaration and Special Declaration [1920] ATS 3 |publisher=Austlii.edu.au |date= |accessdate=15 June 2011}}</ref> They also gave some lands that had been claimed by German Austria to newly formed nation-states. An example of this was the giving of the provinces of [[German Bohemia]] and the [[Province of the Sudetenland|Sudetenland]] to the [[First Czechoslovak Republic|Czecho-Slovak Republic]]. These lands, having German-speaking majorities, were prevented from being within their own nation-state. Instead, they were trapped in the nation-states of other ethnicities.<ref name=bm/> This grievance would play a fundamental part in the rise of pan-Germanism during the [[Interwar period]]. [[Karl Renner]], a member of the [[Social Democratic Workers' Party of Austria|Social Democratic Workers' Party]], served as [[Chancellor of Austria|chancellor]] of German Austria. Renner himself was a proponent of the idea of "Greater Germany", and penned the unofficial anthem ''[[Deutschösterreich, du herrliches Land]]'' ("German Austria, you wonderful country").<ref name="amk"/><ref name="EDT">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=vQqNAAAAIAAJ&q=3203508974&dq=3203508974 | title=Ein deutscher Traum | publisher=Europaverlag | author=Ernst Panzenböck | year=1985 | isbn=3-203-50897-4 | language=German}}</ref> Renner was born in southern [[Moravia]], which was one of the lands claimed by German Austria, but instead given to the Czecho-Slovak Republic. Despite his background, however, he signed the Treaty of Saint-Germain on 10 September 1919, which established the Allied-drawn borders of the new Austrian republic, and formally forbid any attempt to unify the German-speaking lands of the former Austria-Hungary with Germany.<ref name="amk">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=-dmH7FjxassC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0520049551#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=The Austrian Mind: An Intellectual and Social History, 1848–1938 | publisher=University of California Press | author=[[William M. Johnston]] | year=1972 | location=Berkeley | isbn=0-520-04955-1|page=108}}</ref> The name "German Austria" was changed to "Austria", removing any hint of pan-Germanist sentiment from the name of the state. Nevertheless, the Social Democrats would not forget their pan-Germanist roots. To them, the Weimar Republic was regarded with "exaggerated sympathy", whilst the Czecho-Slovak Republic was viewed with "exaggerated suspicion".<ref name="hm2">{{cite book | title=The Habsburg monarchy, 1809–1918: a history of the Austrian Empire and Austria-Hungary | publisher=University of Chicago Press | author=[[A. J. P. Taylor]] | year=1976 | location=Chicago | isbn=0-226-79145-9|page=257|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LMXfMoiI2FgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0226791459#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
==During the First Republic and Austrofascist period (1919–1938)== During the [[First Austrian Republic]], pan-Germanists were represented by the [[Greater German People's Party]] and the agrarian [[Landbund]].<ref>{{Cite book |first=Bruce F. |last=Pauley |title=From Prejudice to Persecution: A History of Austrian Anti-Semitism |publisher=UNC Press Books |year=1998 |page=180 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=PFdSsmxFl7sC&pg=PA188&dq=greater+german+people%27s+party#v=onepage&q=greater%20german%20people%27s%20party&f=false|isbn=9780807847138 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |first=Gernot |last=Stimmer |title=Eliten in Österreich |publisher=Böhlau Verlag |year=1997 |language=German |page=648 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=SNcTu7owGb8C&pg=PA648&dq=gro%C3%9Fdeutsche+volkspartei#v=onepage&q=gro%C3%9Fdeutsche%20volkspartei&f=false|isbn=9783205985877 }}</ref> Although initially influential, these two groups soon lost most of their voters to the [[Christian Social Party (Austria)|Christian Social Party]] and the [[Social Democratic Party of Austria|Social Democratic Party]]. Both the Christian Socials and the Social Democrats accepted that unification between Austria and Germany was forbidden by the Treaty of Saint-Germain. A conflict would develop, however, between those who supported an Austrian national identity, such as the Christian Socials, and those rooted in German nationalism, such as the Social Democrats. [[File:Hitler portrait crop.jpg|thumb|187px|[[Adolf Hitler]], dictator of [[Nazi Germany]], was born in Austria and propagated radical German nationalist views]] One of the foundational problems of the First Republic was that those who had supported the concept of a democratic republic from the German Austria period onward, such as the Social Democrats, did not consider themselves "Austrian", but instead were German nationalists.<ref name="hm3">{{cite book | title=The Habsburg monarchy, 1809–1918: a history of the Austrian Empire and Austria-Hungary | publisher=University of Chicago Press | author=[[A. J. P. Taylor]] | year=1976 | location=Chicago | isbn=0-226-79145-9|page=258|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LMXfMoiI2FgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0226791459#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Those who supported an Austrian national identity, an Austria without the word "German" attached, were conservative and largely undemocratic in persuasion: former Imperial bureaucrats, army officers, priests, aristocrats, and affiliated with the Christian Social Party. In the words of historian [[A. J. P. Taylor]], "The democrats were not 'Austrian'; the 'Austrians' were not democrats."<ref name="hm3"/> These two groups, the German nationalist democrats, and the Austrian nationalist conservatives, would squabble throughout the first decade of the First Republic. Ultimately, the Austrian nationalist faction would overthrow the democratic republic in 1934 and establish [[Federal State of Austria|a regime]] rooted in "[[Austrofascism]]" under the protection of [[Fascist Italy (1922–43)|Fascist Italy]].<ref name="hm3"/><ref name="DSe">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZbqwaF1jq7sC&dq=he+Dollfuss/Schuschnigg+Era+in+Austria:+A+Reassessment |first=Peter |last=Berger |title=The League of Nations and Interwar Austria: Critical Assessment of a Partnership in Economic Reconstruction |work=The Dollfuss/Schuschnigg Era in Austria: A Reassessment |series=Contemporary Austrian Studies |volume=11 | publisher=Transaction Publishers | year=2003 | location=New Brunswick, New Jersey | page=87 | isbn=1-4128-2189-4 |editor1-last=Bischof|editor1-first=Günter|editor2-last=Pelinka |editor2-first=Anton|editor3-last=Lassner |editor3-first=Alexander}}</ref>
While most of right-wing ''[[Heimwehr]]en'' paramilitary groups active during the First Republic were rooted in [[Austrian nationalism]], and either affiliated with the conservative Christian Socials, or inspired by [[Italian Fascism]], there was also a German nationalist faction.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Robert |last=Kriechbaumer |title=Österreich! und Front Heil!: Aus den Akten des Generalsekretariats der Vaterländischen Front – Innenansichten eines Regimes |publisher=Böhlau |year=2005 |page=175}}</ref> This faction was most notable within the [[Styria]]n ''Heimatschutz'' ("homeland protection"). Its leader, [[Walter Pfrimer]], attempted a [[putsch]] against a Christian Social government in September 1931. The putsch was directly modelled on the Benito Mussolini's [[March on Rome]], but failed almost instantly due to lack of support from other ''Heimwehr'' groups. Pfrimer subsequently founded the "German ''Heimatschutz''", which would later merge into the Nazi Party.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Martina |last=Aicher |chapter=Heimwehren (Österreich) |title=Organisationen, Institutionen, Bewegungen |series=Handbuch des Antisemitismus |volume=5 |publisher=de Gruyter |year=2012 |page=310}}</ref>
The idea of an ''Anschluss'' (union between Austria and Germany to form a [[Greater Germany]]), was one of the principle ideas of the Austrian branch of the [[Austrian National Socialism|National Socialist]] (Nazi) Party. Nazism can be seen as descended from the radical branches of the pan-Germanist movement.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Bruce F. |last=Pauley |title=From Prejudice to Persecution: A History of Austrian Anti-Semitism |publisher=UNC Press Books |year=1998 |page=189 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=PFdSsmxFl7sC&pg=PA188&dq=greater+german+people%27s+party#v=onepage&q=greater%20german%20people%27s%20party&f=false|isbn=9780807847138 }}</ref> In 1933, the Nazis and the Greater German People's Party formed a joint working-group, and eventually merged.<ref>{{cite book |title= Fascism in Europe, 1919–1945 |last= Morgan |first= Philip |year= 2003 |publisher= Routledge |isbn= 0-415-16942-9 |page= 72 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ZVGAZJWJOWkC}}</ref> During the period while the Nazi Party and its symbols were banned in Austria, from 1933 to 1938, Austrian Nazis resumed the earlier pan-Germanist tradition of wearing a blue cornflower in their buttonhole.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Thomas |last=Dostal |title=Das 'braune Netzwerk' in Linz: Die illegalen nationalsozialistischen Aktivitäten zwischen 1933 und 1938 |work=Nationalsozialismus in Linz |volume=1 |publisher=Archiv der Stadt Linz |year=2002 |page=116}}</ref> [[File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-1987-0922-500,_Wien,_Heldenplatz,_Rede_Adolf_Hitler.jpg|left|thumb|325px|Hitler announces the Anschluss to roughly 200,000 German Austrians on the Heldenplatz, Vienna, 15 March 1938.]] The Nazis firmly fought the [[Austrofascism|Austrofascist]] regime of chancellor [[Engelbert Dollfuss]], and orchestrated his assassination. They continued this battle against his successor, [[Kurt Schuschnigg]]. Austrofacism was strongly supported by [[Benito Mussolini]], leader of [[Fascist Italy (1922–43)|Fascist Italy]]. Mussolini's support for an independent Austria can be seen in a discussion he had with Prince [[Ernst Rüdiger Starhemberg]], an important Austrian nationalist and Heimwehr leader. He said that "an Anschluss with Germany must never be permitted ... Austria is necessary to the maintenance of Europe ... the day that Austria falls and is swallowed up by Germany will mark the beginning of European chaos."<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=7SWt-F9wbr0C&q=Between+Hitler+and+Mussolini&dq=Between+Hitler+and+Mussolini | title=Between Hitler and Mussolini | publisher=Harper & Brothers Publishers | author=Ernst Rüdiger, Prince of Starhemberg | year=1942 | location=London | page=26}}</ref> The Austrofascist party, [[Fatherland Front (Austria)|Fatherland Front]], would echo the sentiments of Mussolini, and continue to struggle for an independent Austria. Nazis in both Germany and Austria intended that the [[Nazi Germany|German Reich]] would quickly annex Austria, the homeland of its leader, [[Adolf Hitler]]. They attempted to bribe many low-ranking [[Heimwehr]] leaders, and also attempted to bring Starhemberg into their fold, in effect merging the Heimwehr with the Nazi [[Freikorps]].<ref name=BHM2>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=7SWt-F9wbr0C&q=Between+Hitler+and+Mussolini&dq=Between+Hitler+and+Mussolini | title=Between Hitler and Mussolini | publisher=Harper & Brothers Publishers | author=Ernst Rüdiger, Prince of Starhemberg | year=1942 | location=London | pages=36–45}}</ref> [[Gregor Strasser]], an early, prominent Nazi figure, was charged with this effort. When Starhemberg, a fervent believer in an independent Austria, rejected his merger proposal, Strasser said "Don't talk to me about Austria. There is no Austria ... there was once a living corpse which called itself Austria ... that this Austria collapsed in 1918 was a blessing ... particularly for the German people, who were thereby given the chance to create a Greater Germany."<ref name=BHM2/>
After this, tensions between the Nazis and Austrofascists worsened, culminating in the [[July Putsch]] of 1934, when Nazis attempted to overthrow the government. Whilst they managed to assassinate chancellor [[Engelbert Dollfuss]], the putsch was quickly crushed by the police, army, and Heimwehren. In the aftermath of the putsch, conflict between the Social Democrats and the ruling Austrofascists led to the [[Austrian Civil War]] later in the year. After their defeat, the Social Democratic Party was outlawed entirely. This, in tandem with a continued a campaign of violence and propaganda by the Nazis, destabilised the Austrofascist regime, and rallied many to support the idea of ''[[Anschluss]]''.<ref name="OSe">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Österreich.html?id=PAHLAAAACAAJ | title=Österreich: eine tausendjährige Geschichte | publisher=Heyne | author=Gordon Brook-Shepherd | year=2000 | isbn=3-453-16343-5}}</ref>
The Nazi campaign was ultimately successful, and Hitler would go on to annex Austria in 1938 with the ''Anschluss''. Hitler's journey through his home country Austria became a triumphal tour that reached its climax in [[Vienna]] on 15 March 1938, when around 200,000 cheering German Austrians gathered around the ''[[Heldenplatz]]'' (Square of Heroes) to hear Hitler say that "The oldest eastern province of the German people shall be, from this point on, the newest bastion of the German Reich"<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFb2-sYf6XIC&pg=PA184&lpg=PA184&dq='The+oldest+eastern+...+German+people+shall+be,+from+this+point+on,+the+newest+bastion+of+the+German+Reich#v=onepage&q='The%20oldest%20eastern%20...%20German%20people%20shall%20be%2C%20from%20this%20point%20on%2C%20the%20newest%20bastion%20of%20the%20German%20Reich&f=false|page=184|title=The German Myth of the East: 1800 to the Present|first=Vejas Gabriel|last=Liulevicius|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|year=2009|isbn=9780191610462}}</ref> followed by his "greatest accomplishment" (completing the annexing of Austria to form a Greater German Reich) by saying: "As leader and chancellor of the German nation and Reich I announce to German history now the entry of my homeland into the German Reich."<ref>In German: "Als Führer und Kanzler der deutschen Nation und des Reiches melde ich vor der deutschen Geschichte nunmehr den Eintritt meiner Heimat in das Deutsche Reich."</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://aeiou.iicm.tugraz.at/aeiou.film.data.film/f107a.mpg|title=Video: Hitler proclaims Austria's inclusion in the Reich (2 MB)|accessdate=11 March 2007}}</ref> After the ''Anschluss'', Hitler remarked as a personal note: "I, myself, as Führer and Chancellor, will be happy to walk on the soil of the country that is my home as a free German citizen."<ref>{{cite book|author=James Giblin|title=The Life and Death of Adolf Hitler|year=2002|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=0-395-90371-8|page=110}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=John Toland|title=Adolf Hitler: The Definitive Biography|date=23 September 2014|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-101-87277-2|page=450}}</ref>
Hitler responded to the foreign press regarding the ''Anschluss'' by saying: "Certain foreign newspapers have said that we fell on Austria with brutal methods. I can only say: even in death they cannot stop lying. I have in the course of my political struggle won much love from my people, but when I crossed the former frontier (into Austria) there met me such a stream of love as I have never experienced. Not as tyrants have we come, but as liberators."<ref>William L. Shirer, The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany, p.349</ref>
Following the ''Anschluss'', the historical aim of the German nationalists who supported the union between Austria and Germany was completed.<ref name="Bideleux"/> The pan-Germanists were then fully absorbed into the [[Nazi Party]] (NSDAP).<ref name="Pelinka">{{Cite book |first=Anton |last=Pelinka |title=Die FPÖ im internationalen Vergleich: Zwischen Rechtspopulismus, Deutschnationalismus und Österreich-Patriotismus |journal=Conflict & communication online |volume=1, |number=1 |year=2002 |language=German |page=7 |url=http://www.cco.regener-online.de/2002_1/pdf_2002_1/pelinka.pdf}}</ref>
==During the Second Republic (since 1945)==
After the end of the [[Second World War]], when [[Allied occupation of Austria|Austria]] was re-established as an independent state, the German nationalist movement was discredited because of its links to the former Nazi regime.<ref name="Pelinka"/> The dominant parties of the new republic were the Christian conservative [[Austrian People's Party]] and the Socialist Party. Both promoted Austrian independence, and considered the idea of a "Greater Germany" an anachronism. All former members of the Nazi party were banned from any political activity, and disenfranchised.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Ionas Aurelian |last=Rus |title=Variables affecting nation-building: The impact of the ethnic basis, the educational system, industrialization and sudden shocks |year=2008 |page=435 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=8bx32zNOxX4C&pg=PA433&dq=freedom+party+austria+german+nationalism#v=onepage&q=freedom%20party%20austria%20german%20nationalism&f=false|isbn=9781109059632 }}</ref> The pan-Germanist and liberal "Third Camp" was later revived in the form of the [[Federation of Independents]] ({{lang-de|Verband der Unabhängigen}}), which fought [[de-Nazification]] laws imposed by the [[Allies (World War II)|Allies]], and represented the interests of former Nazis, [[Wehrmacht]], and [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] soldiers. In 1956, the Federation was transformed into the [[Freedom Party of Austria]]. In the 1950s and 1960s, the German nationalist movement, represented by the Freedom Party and its affiliated organisations, was very active in universities, where the ''[[Burschenschaft]]en'', a type of student fraternity, helped spread German nationalist and liberal views. Inside the Freedom Party, the liberal wing grew to overtake the pan-Germanist wing, and Austrian patriotism was gradually incorporated into the party's ideology.<ref name="Pelinka"/><ref name="Gingrich_Banks">{{Cite book |first1=André |last1=Gingrich |first2=Marcus |last2=Banks |title=Neo-nationalism in Europe & beyond |publisher=Berghahn Books |year=2006 |page=148 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=zScJs9HjixQC&pg=PA148&dq=freedom+party+austria+german+nationalism#v=onepage&q=german%20nationalism&f=false|isbn=9781845451905 }}</ref> During [[Norbert Steger]]'s party leadership during 1980–1986, and the Freedom Party's participation in a coalition government with the Social Democrats, the pan-Germanist faction was weakened further.<ref name="Pelinka2">{{Cite book |first=Anton |last=Pelinka |title=Jörg Haiders "Freiheitliche" – ein nicht nur österreichisches Problem |work=Liberalismus in Geschichte und Gegenwart |publisher=Königshausen & Neumann |year=2000 |language=German |page=235 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=NWmudq4s4GAC&pg=PA233&dq=deutschnational+freiheitliche#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
By contrast, [[Jörg Haider]]'s assumption of party leadership in 1986 was considered a triumph by the German nationalist faction.<ref name="Gingrich_Banks"/><ref name="Pelinka2"/> However, Haider's [[right-wing populism]] did not stress pan-Germanist traditions, as doing so would have cost votes. In 1987, only six percent of Austrian citizens identified themselves as "Germans".<ref>{{Cite book |first=Ernst |last=Bruckmüller |title=Die Entwicklung des Österreichbewußtseins |year=1998 |page=17 |url=http://www.hkbu.edu.hk/~europe/euro-ach/a/intro/texte/bruckmueller.pdf}}</ref> While Haider had branded Austrian national identity as an ideological construct, going so far to refer to it as a "monstrosity" ''({{lang-de|Mißgeburt}})'' in 1988, he launched the "Austria First" [[petition]] in 1993, and claimed two years later that the Freedom Party was a "classical Austrian patriotic party", expressly renouncing his earlier "monstrosity" statement.<ref name="Bruckmüller40">{{Cite book |first=Ernst |last=Bruckmüller |title=Nation Österreich: Kulturelles Bewusstsein und gesellschaftlich-politische Prozesse |publisher=Böhlau |year=1996 |page=40}}</ref> The influence of German nationalism was still present, however, and could be seen in hostile actions against Slavic minorities in Austria, such as in conflicts over bilingual road sign with the [[Carinthian Slovenes]], along with hostility to [[immigration]] and [[European integration]].<ref name="Pelinka"/> Traditional Greater German ideas have therefore been replaced by a German-Austrian concept (i.e. only considering Austrians of German origin and tongue as "real" Austrians).<ref name="Bruckmüller40"/> This may be summarised as an "amalgamation of traditional German nationalism with Austrian patriotism".<ref>{{Cite book |first1=Anton |last1=Pelinka |first2=Hubert |last2=Sickinger |first3=Karin |last3=Stögner |title=Kreisky – Haider: Bruchlinien österreichischer Identitäten |publisher=Braumüller |year=2008 |page=18}}</ref>
Presently, the pan-Germanist wing is only a minor faction within the Freedom Party. In 2008, fewer than seventeen percent of the Freedom Party's voters questioned the existence of a unique Austrian national identity.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Österreicher fühlen sich heute als Nation |newspaper=Der Standard |date=12 March 2008 |language=German |url=http://derstandard.at/3261105 |accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref> German nationalists, including [[Andreas Mölzer]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://diepresse.com/home/politik/euwahl/464619/index?gal=464619&index=3&direct=466658&_vl_backlink=/home/politik/eu/index.do&popup=|work=[[Die Presse]]|language=German|title=Ab nach Brüssel?: Die Spitzenkandidaten für die EU-Wahl|accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref> and [[Martin Graf]],<ref name="dpkul">{{cite news | url=http://diepresse.com/home/kultur/medien/763208/Eine-stete-GrafWanderung&usg=ALkJrhiMNQBFnzHJRc2LPv7Vx0TKAY_q-A | title=Eine stete Graf-Wanderung | work=Die Presse | date=4 June 2012 | accessdate=10 July 2014 | author=Regina Pöll | language=German}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |newspaper=Zur Zeit |page=2 |issue=43 |year=2008}}</ref> now refer to themselves as "cultural Germans" (''Kulturdeutsche''), and stress the importance of their identity as ethnic Germans, in contrast to the distinct [[Austrians#Republic of Austria .281955 to present.29|Austrian national identity]]. In 2006, FPÖ members of parliament reaffirmed the party's root in the pan-Germanist tradition, at least symbolically, by wearing blue cornflowers in their buttonholes, along with ribbons in Austria's national colours (red and white), during the initial meeting of the [[National Council (Austria)|National Council]]. This caused controversy, as the media interpreted the flower as a former Nazi symbol.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Anklänge an illegale NSDAPler |publisher=ORF.at |url=http://newsv1.orf.at/061030-5431/index.html |date=30 October 2006}}</ref>
